content: Then, if you fuck up, you have two options. The first is to say: I‚Äôm not actually what you think I am, that‚Äôs all just projection‚Äîyour teacher is flawed, just as you will be, no matter how long you stare at walls and chant mantras. But you could also double down on the behavior, and say: if only you were me, you would understand why everything I‚Äôm doing is perfectly good.

If you‚Äôre interested in substantially emulating them or trusting them with your emotional health, you should ask around about how they are personally. Cool, they taught you some excellent spiritual tools‚Äîdo they pay their employees on time?

If awakening can‚Äôt cure narcissism, it‚Äôs no longer troubling that a guru could have tremendous insights into the clear light nature of your consciousness, while still being wrapped up in scandals.

Anyway, narcissists are narcissists‚Äîthey like prominence, perhaps a little bit more than the rest of us do. This directly implies that spiritual teachers who draw a lot of attention to their own flawlessness, attainments, et cetera, are perhaps more likely to be the ones without a tremendous degree of moral development. And thus, they are the ones whose falls-from-grace cast the most doubt on the idea of awakening.

Meanwhile, I‚Äôve noticed that high-profile teachers who behave extremely well are often embedded in a community of teachers they consider equals, or have a permanent teacher of their own. This way, it‚Äôs not just their own conscience they‚Äôre accountable to‚Äîsomeone else can always poke their head in and say, ‚ÄúHey, from one awakened being to another, your sangha is really fucked up. What the fuck is going on?‚Äù

Even if Bob is well-intentioned, which is not a given, where do you expect this situation to go? We‚Äôre rolling some crooked dice here‚Äîlet‚Äôs roll them for twenty years. Do you think Bob is never going to act inappropriately, even if he‚Äôs unusually psychologically aware? Perhaps he‚Äôs always ethically pure‚Äîgreat, let‚Äôs check up on the other 200 spiritual teachers in Berkeley.

‚ÄúYou start by pulling up the big weeds, then you move onto the medium weeds, and then the really tiny weeds. And if you think you‚Äôve got all the tiny weeds, it‚Äôs probably because there‚Äôs a big weed that grew behind you, and you don‚Äôt see it yet.‚Äù
In Ken Wilber language, you can ‚Äúwake up‚Äù a bunch, and then have a big lag in the ‚Äúcleaning up‚Äù department.

Obviously, no. Competitive athletes have honed their fitness to the point where they can deliberately enter insane situations, and this creates the risk of damage. It‚Äôs similar for spiritual teachers.

title: A highly opinionated guide to learning about ActivityPub
author: tinysubversions.com
summary: This guide helps programmers learn about ActivityPub by emphasizing the importance of reading additional specs beyond the ActivityPub spec. title: How to implement a basic ActivityPub server
author: Eugen Rochko
summary: This text explains how to set up a basic ActivityPub server to send messages in Mastodon. It covers creating an ActivityPub actor with a JSON-LD document, implementing Webfinger for user discovery, and using HTTP signatures for secure message delivery. The process involves generating RSA keypairs, defining actor properties, and sending messages with proper signatures to interact within the federated network.

title: Threads has entered the fediverse
author: Simon Blackstein

The platform's integration with the fediverse presents technical challenges and opportunities, aiming to offer users greater control over their online identity and content. Users can now federate their profiles, enabling interaction with people on different social networking services built on the same protocol. Threads plans to expand its federated features, ensuring a seamless experience for both federated and non-federated users while aiming to become fully interoperable within the fediverse in the future.

title: ‚ÄòApple Aggregates AI‚Äô
author: John Gruber
summary:
Ben Thompson:

So what is Apple Intelligence, then? To me the explanation flows directly from Strategy 101: Apple Intelligence is the application of generative AI to use cases and content that Apple is uniquely positioned to provide and access. It is designed, to build on yesterday‚Äôs Article, to maximize the advantages that Apple has in terms of being the operating system provider on your phone; and, on the other hand, what it is not is any sort of general purpose chatbot: that is where OpenAI comes in‚Äâ‚Äî‚Äâand only there. [‚Ä¶]
To put it another way, and in Stratechery terms, Apple is positioning itself as an AI Aggregator: the company owns users and, by extension, generative AI demand by virtue of owning its platforms, and it is deepening its moat through Apple Intelligence, which only Apple can do; that demand is then being brought to bear on suppliers who probably have to eat the costs of getting privileged access to Apple‚Äôs userbase.

It pains me to admit how great a take this is. Nailed it.

title: Transaction Script
author: martinfowler.com
summary: Transaction Script is an approach to organizing business logic in which each procedure handles a single request from the presentation. Most business applications can be seen as a series of transactions, each containing a certain amount of logic. Transaction Script organizes this logic as a single procedure, making calls directly to the database or through a thin database wrapper. Each transaction has its own Transaction Script, but common subtasks can be broken into subprocedures.

Once or twice a week, we‚Äôd go over to the senior apartment where my grandparents lived and talk about times when doctors arrived on sleds and kids slaughtered rabbits for profit, and once a week, we‚Äôd go into the city. The rest of the time was wide open.

I kept a notebook where I jotted down things I wanted to google and twice a week I‚Äôd go down to the local library, look at the list, and say, why on earth did I want to know Justin Bieber‚Äôs net worth? And then I‚Äôd go home again, to read and write, listen and talk.

The early experiments were often stupid. But it didn‚Äôt matter, because the few that worked for us (like radically reducing our use of the internet, like starting a blog) paid for all of the others, by opening up unseen possibilities. Experiments have capped downside but unknown upside.

When we were thinking about getting internet, we said: well, what are the arguments for having internet? We listed them. The arguments didn‚Äôt convince us, so we spent a year without internet. Then we got 1 GB surf so we could check our email.

This is admittedly a strange and rather mechanical way of talking about relationships, and I do not, on the average Monday, think about me and Johanna in these terms. But it is a useful framing to think of a relationship as something you can iterate on and eventually become exceptionally good at. There is love in that care.

The best scientists aren‚Äôt those who are the most intelligent; they are the ones who tweak their theories further than others, in close contact with experimental reality. The most valuable startups didn't start with product-market fit. They kept learning and adjusting at a faster pace than those who fell behind. The same can be said of relationships. You need to keep a certain rate of improvement for things not to break.
Johanna is conscientious about making sure she understands, asking many detailed questions. She listens, holding you to what you say. This made living and growing with her (relatively) easy.

There is a corollary for relationships. Some relationships are hard, or even impossible, to change. As an individual, you grow‚Äîbut your father won‚Äôt acknowledge that change or adapt to it, and the relationship gets stuck. Other relationships are fluid and open-ended, they grow to fit you better and better the more time you invest in them, like an old house where you rearrange the walls, doors, and furniture until the light falls just right.

Not all houses age like this. For it to happen, Brand writes, the design must allow you to ‚Äúmess around with it and progressively change it to bring it into an adapted state with yourself, your family, the climate, whatever.‚Äù Often, modern houses make this harder.
The design choices were layered with insights that had occurred over decades of lived experience. It was an architectural manifestation of my grandparents.

I could chart a path through life that made no compromises for others, and it would go where I wanted it to; or I could impose the much stricter rigor that comes from aligning my trajectory with Johanna‚Äôs, seeking mutual flourishing, and I‚Äôd be surprised where life would take me.

We‚Äôd been a couple for 18 months at this point. The last ten weeks, the South American off-season, we‚Äôd spent moving between empty hotels along the Peruvian coast and up the Andes, scribbling in our notebooks, reading, getting to know each other better. In another two weeks, we‚Äôd be heading home.

This is what I infer when I see someone who is comfortable in their unique strangeness, too. There probably exists someone who enabled that evolution of personality. A parent, a friend group, a spouse. It is rare for people to come into themselves if no one is excited and curious about their core, their potential. We need someone who gives us space to unfold.
‚ÄúDependence is scorned even in intimate relationships, as though dependence were incompatible with self-reliance rather than the only thing that makes it possible.‚Äù
That‚Äôs how I felt about Johanna back then: I didn‚Äôt want her as my girlfriend, I just wanted her as a human being. I just wanted her around. I still feel that way.

Which was interesting, because Johanna herself was introverted and largely kept her thoughts private. But she had the same effect on me: the words that came out of my mouth when I talked to her continually surprised me. I didn‚Äôt know I had so much in me. I hadn‚Äôt known who I was until I talked to her.

When they saw us in the street, the homeless would come running.

content: Or you can prompt them by yourself going into uncharted territory, perhaps thinking aloud about something that confuses you. And you make sure to do so in a way that leaves room for them to use their experience to reason about what you are saying.

If you want to prompt someone to be authentic and playful and generative, you usually just need to ask them something where they have a rich experience to pull from but have never pulled an answer from that experience before.

The Reverend is talking about how the Lord works in mysterious ways, and so on‚Äîit is exactly the type of conversation you want to avoid. It is very ChatGPT. It is the Reverend repeating things he‚Äôs said before‚Äîwords that protect him, that allow him to perform the role of Reverend, instead of being what he is: a man named Lopez, who will soon have to watch a boy die.

The type of person I‚Äôm assuming we‚Äôre looking for here is 1) someone that you will find fascinating to talk to after you‚Äôve talked for 20,000 hours, 2) you feel comfortable with them talking through the hardest and most painful decisions you will face in your life, and 3) the conversation is wildly generative for both of you, in that it brings you out, helps you become.

But I do think it is a good idea, generally, and one that I have used‚Äîto speedrun relationships by jumping directly to the strange parts. There is really no point in going to a caf√© to talk safely (if you can avoid it). You want to rapidly extract as much information as possible, so you can figure out what you like and so that you can pattern match, and you want to communicate as much as possible, too, so you can filter people who wouldn‚Äôt fit you anyway (which is why keeping a blog is good).

Johanna looked at me mesmerized: to see someone work so hard for something, and with such delicate care, and then, on the day of his success, decide to gamble it all on the move, let‚Äôs be self-obsessed and say things that people find revolting about me.

Here I was, clearly having been obsessed with her for one and a half years, which we both knew, and finally, I was being led into her bedroom, a room strewn waist-deep with books and half-finished canvases stacked against the walls, and I decided that this was the right time to talk about how ashamed I was with myself, and how out of control my life was.

You can apparently inverse that too: if you talk about anything that pops into your mind, you can tell if you're supposed to be with the person by judging their reaction. Most ‚Äúdates‚Äù would have been hurt by my monologue that night, or bored, or appalled.

content: That is perhaps the most solid dating advice I have, by the way‚Äîshow the inside of your head in public, so people can see if they would like to live in there.

When someone you resonate with is reluctant, you have to be very alert to moods. Make sure you are the one that backs off before they do. Signal that what you like is this particular thing right here right now, not anything that you are hoping to game it into. And don‚Äôt flirt. But keep talking.
And the thing is, there aren‚Äôt that many people you can have an amazing life with. Maybe 10,000, spread fairly evenly across the globe? A bit more if you‚Äôre less weird than me, perhaps.

You can learn a lot by observing how people hang out with their friends. She laughed like a hyena, and they were obsessing over some obscure book, and they were so raw and cute. I‚Äôd never been as intrigued by a human being before.

The first time I met Johanna, on September 11, 2011, I was having a poetry reading in a bookstore. I was twenty-two. I figured she was probably there to see me. She was not there to see me. A month later, hungover in a caf√©, we met again.

So, as I was saying, by my early twenties I had reached this stage. I had crashed and burned through a couple of relationships. I had tried a lot of weird things. And now I could sort of gesture at what I liked‚Äîkind people who are intellectually voracious and think it is cute that I obsess so hard about ideas that I fail all status games.
So what do you do? You go talk to a thousand people (increasingly less randomly sampled) and see if there are any patterns in who makes you feel excited and alive and true and heard.

But instead of thinking that was a mean girl, update the neural net to avoid traits A, B, and C, they go, oh, you know . . . girls. Or, they do the same to themselves: I have a weakness for that type. They also think about relationships in categorical terms.

This happens to everyone, I guess. But some of my friends are noticeably worse at generalizing from their experiences. They keep making similar mistakes. Why is that? My guess is that those who predictably date the wrong people tend to think more categorically.
The first thing to realize is that, unless you have found one, you don‚Äôt actually know what an Alice is.
Someone once asked Gertrude Stein if she was a lesbian. Stein answered no, I just like Alice.

title: Astro Islands
author: Astro Documentation
summary: Astro Islands, also known as Component Islands, are a web architecture pattern that allows for interactive UI components on otherwise static HTML pages. Multiple islands can exist on a page, each rendering in isolation and created with any supported UI framework. Astro leverages the technique of partial or selective hydration to generate websites with zero client-side JavaScript by default, making them faster and more lightweight. The benefits of Astro Islands include improved performance, parallel loading, and the ability to selectively load components as needed.

title: Why Astro?
author: Astro Documentation
summary: Astro is an all-in-one web framework designed for building fast, content-focused websites. It offers several core design principles, including a focus on content, server-first rendering, fast performance, ease of use, and flexibility. Astro is particularly suited for content-rich websites such as marketing sites, blogs, and portfolios. It takes a multi-page app (MPA) approach, leveraging server-side rendering to deliver excellent performance. Astro aims to make building fast websites easier by reducing complexity and providing a comprehensive set of features. It also supports integration with other popular UI frameworks and offers flexibility for developers to bring their own UI framework.

The OG two-door RAV4 feels emblematic of this moment when the American automotive market could still accommodate cars that tight. Whereas the newer RAV4s are not swag. They could be any SUV.

Also I was binge-watching every episode of Shark Tank, and seeing that kind of desperate yet weirdly confident energy a lot of the people on that show have, pushing themselves into this situation where you‚Äôre like, ‚ÄòYou don‚Äôt need to do this.‚Äô But I think a lot of people are like, ‚ÄòThis is the American dream.‚Äô

content: The indirectness of cultural strategies is apparent in their account of how they affect material outcomes in the world: you do a bunch of work to build up a cultural movement, the movement manages to change ‚Äúthe culture,‚Äù and then that finally inspires someone else to actually do something real. Or at least that‚Äôs the hope. More likely, it just inspires them to do something ‚Äúin culture‚Äù like you did.

Despite their sincere belief that they are helping and assurances that they ‚Äútotally support the movement,‚Äù these imitators are actually the most dangerous political enemies of any real project. title: On Bullshit
author: Harry Frankfurt
summary: The text from "On Bullshit" discusses the concept of humbug and its relation to lying and bullshit. It explores how humbug involves deceptive misrepresentation, short of lying, especially by pretentious word or deed, of one's own thoughts, feelings, or attitudes. The text also delves into the nature of bullshit, highlighting that it is not necessarily false but rather phony, with the bullshitter faking things and being indifferent to the truth. Bullshitting is compared to lying, with the former often being seen as more tolerated than the latter. The text concludes by discussing why there is so much bullshit, attributing it to situations where people talk without knowing what they are talking about due to excessive obligations or opportunities to speak on a topic.

summary: Nothing gets me quite as fired up as discovering the future early and undistributed. It's amazing, and it's how I'm feeling about Linux right now. That "how did I not know it was this good" sensation.I felt the same way about the Mac back in 2001. And Ruby in 2003. And company chat with Campfire in 2005. And, fast forward, now with #nobuild, Hotwire, and even exiting the cloud. When I discover a path that seems like a clear shortcut, it doesn't really matter if it's poorly paved at first. As long as it appears to take us somewhere better, laying the bricks and clearing the brush is incidental.It's about seeing that end state. Where what's right in front of us now, rough and unpolished as it may be, can be transformed, if we put in the effort, that inspires me to keep going.Yes, half the fun is the adventure. content: Every post. Every day. About 75% of the time you compose a post, you will get halfway through writing it and think ‚ÄúI can‚Äôt deal with the replies this will get today‚Äù and delete it. You stop talking about things you enjoy, because you‚Äôre tired of people shitting on them.
You want to squee about something you‚Äôre enjoying that‚Äôs making you happy? There will be 40 people coming to scold you because that thing isn‚Äôt morally pure enough.

The people who look at a post that contains no question marks and think ‚Äúthere is an implied question here and I will answer it!‚Äù and leap to offer the most basic advice that you already thought of because you have existed for more than three seconds and can, in fact, think of the obvious answers.

And then those people start reposting your more viral threads, and you get people following you who are three degrees of separation from the people you are most likely to vibe with. And three degrees of separation is the second degradation threshold.
I don‚Äôt have enough of a shared social context to gauge what an unknown proportion of my followers feel is appropriate.

content: Approaches like microservices and SoA are tools that allow technical organizations to avoid coordinating over things like data models, implementation choices, fleet management, tool choices, and other things that aren‚Äôt core to their businesses.
Oh this is an interesting way of thinking about it

Just like computer systems, organizations scale by avoiding coordination. The more the organization needs different pieces to coordinate with one another to work, the less it is going to be able to grow.
Simplicity is a property of systems, not components. Systems include people and processes.

Reacting to customer issues. In distributed systems, its typical to take advantage of the high availability mechanisms of the system to allow for safe zero-impact patching and deployments. Single-machine systems are harder to change.

title: nsdi20-paper-agache
MemoryDB: Speed, Durability, and Composition.
author: Marc Brooker
summary: The MemoryDB paper discusses a fast, durable database with compatibility with Redis and improved performance through composition in distributed systems. It highlights the benefits of breaking down systems into simpler pieces and optimizing components for specific tasks in distributed systems. The use of off-box snapshotting in MemoryDB demonstrates how distributed systems can improve performance by separating different operations efficiently.

title: Exponential Value at Linear Cost
author: Marc Brooker
summary: Marc Brooker, an engineer at Amazon Web Services, discusses the concept of exponential value at linear cost in computing. He explains that certain aspects of computing, such as binary search and redundancy, offer exponential value in relation to the amount of effort required. However, he also notes that this powerful effect of redundancy only works when the redundant components fail independently. If there is correlation between their failures, the system's availability is significantly reduced. System designers must be aware of this and consider it when designing distributed systems.

content: Availability. Systems made up of multiple redundant components can offer levels of availability that single-machine systems simply can‚Äôt match. Distributed systems achieve exponentially better availability at linear cost, in a way that‚Äôs almost entirely hands-off.
Scale, and scalability, is only a small part of the overall reason distributed systems are interesting.
Many very important workloads can fit on one such machine.

This argument is based on a kernel of truth: modern machines are extremely powerful, can do vast amounts of work every second, and can fit all the data belonging to even some rather large businesses in memory. Thousands, or even millions, of requests per second are achievable. Hundreds of gigabits per second.
You don‚Äôt need distributed systems! Computers are so fast these days you can serve all your customers off a single machine!

title: Not Just Scale
author: marcbrooker@gmail.com (Marc Brooker)
summary:
Not Just Scale
Bookmarking this so I can stop writing it over and over.
It seems like everywhere I look on the internet these days, somebody‚Äôs making some form of the following argument:

You don‚Äôt need distributed systems! Computers are so fast these days you can serve all your customers off a single machine!

This argument is silly and reductive.
But first, let‚Äôs look for the kernel of truth.
One Machine Is All You Need?
This argument is based on a kernel of truth: modern machines are extremely powerful, can do vast amounts of work every second, and can fit all the data belonging to even some rather large businesses in memory. Thousands, or even millions, of requests per second are achievable. Hundreds of gigabits per second. Terabytes of memory, and even more storage. Gigabytes per second of storage bandwidth. Millions of IOPS. Modern machines are super fast, and software which can take advantage of that speed can achieve incredible things.
It‚Äôs also true that many systems are distributed thoughtlessly, or wa...

content: Our ability to predict the future is never as certain in the real world as in the classroom. No matter how compelling the math, the best chalkboard decision might not be the best overall move.

The math says lever up, reduce inventory, pay your employees as little as possible, charge your customers as much as possible, and take advantage of the weakness of your suppliers. You don't need to look far to see companies who take this approach. In the short term, these decisions almost always seem optimal. In the long term, they almost always fail.

What if we have a pandemic? What if the stock market drops 20% or 30%? What if mortgage rates rise 10%? Can you handle these events with equanimity, or will circumstances force you to do something you don't want to do?
The math always points to the optimal immediate decision, which is rarely the best long-term decision.
There is a certain category of decisions that work well in the classroom but not in real life. I call these chalkboard decisions. These decisions tease us because the math always seems correct.

content: You simply can't dunk someone into submission, and it's usually counterproductive if you try. But you can absolutely attract people who aren't happy with their current circumstances to give an alternative a chance, if you simply show them how it works, and allow them to conclude by themselves how it would make their programming life better.

Showing something great, and letting those who weren't happy with their current situation become inspired to check it out. Because those are the only people who is able to convert to your cause anyway.

Which didn't contain a single comparison to other named solutions or specifically pointed arguments against alternatives. It just showed what you could do with Ruby on Rails, and the A/B comparison automatically ran inside the mind of every programmer who was exposed to that.

title: Why I retired from the tech crusades
author: David Heinemeier Hansson (dhh@hey.com)
summary: When Ruby on Rails was launched over twenty years ago, I was a twenty-some young programmer convinced that anyone who gave my stack a try would accept its universal superiority for solving The Web Problem. So I pursued the path of the crusade, attempting to convert the unenlightened masses by the edge of a pointed argument.And for a long time, I thought that's what had worked. That this was why Ruby on Rails took off, became one of the most popular full-stack web frameworks of all time, inspired countless clones, and created hundreds of billions in enterprise value for companies built on it. But I was wrong. title: Command-line Tools can be 235x Faster than your Hadoop Cluster
author: Adam Drake
summary: Using command-line tools can be significantly faster than using a Hadoop cluster for data processing tasks. By creating a data pipeline with shell commands, all processing steps can be done in parallel, resulting in faster performance. Shell commands like grep and awk can be used to filter and process data efficiently. The author demonstrates this by comparing the speed of processing chess game data using Hadoop versus command-line tools. The command-line tools were able to process the same amount of data 235 times faster than the Hadoop implementation. The author suggests that for many data processing tasks, using simple shell commands and tools on a single machine can be more efficient and cost-effective than using complex distributed processing systems like Hadoop.

content: ‚ÄúAnything you do to optimize your work, cut some corners, or squeeze more ‚Äòefficiency‚Äô out of it (and out of your life) will eventually make you dislike it.‚Äù

I sometimes fantasize about doing a series of ‚ÄúLife Hacks I Won‚Äôt Be Attempting.‚Äù A Reddit commenter suggested that you can use your phone‚Äôs image text recognition capability to instantly find any book in your home. But I am not interested in the instant retrieval of any book I own! Part of the beauty and joy of going to the bookshelf is all the books you bump into before you find the one you‚Äôre looking for. (I believe so strongly in this serendipity of the stacks that I don‚Äôt even organize my books.)

During a recent phone call, my friend Matt Thomas told me he likes to take a high/low approach to balancing his input, which started when he was in grad school reading dense theoretical texts by day and chasing them with movies like Fast Five at night.

Hokusai believed in continuous artistic growth, expressing his hope to achieve a divine state in his art at the age of 100.

title: Why Android developers no longer need Windows USB drivers
author: fabiensanglard.net
summary: Android developers no longer need Windows USB drivers to connect their devices. In the early days of Android, Linux and Mac OS X users could connect their devices with a USB cable, while Windows users had to find and install drivers. Nowadays, all three major operating systems come with default drivers, but in case no driver can be found, Windows 8 has a better way than INF files to discover which driver an interface needs. With this method, there is no need for drivers anymore.

title: A captivating summer 2007
author: fabiensanglard.net
summary: The summer of 2007 saw the release of the iPhone, which was not available in Canada until a year later. The iPhone Dev Team, committed to openness, worked to enable the device to run on any carrier. They achieved this by completing six milestones, including understanding the system, bypassing activation, and unlocking the baseband. They also found a solution to write in the system partition.

title: The hearts of the Super Nintendo
author: fabiensanglard.net
summary: The Super Nintendo has multiple clocks that control different components like the CPU and audio chips. These clocks are generated by crystal oscillators and ceramic resonators on the motherboard. The clocks are crucial for the system's performance and can be adjusted to prevent issues like the console displaying in black and white.

title: The evolution of the Super Nintendo motherboard
author: fabiensanglard.net
summary: Nintendo evolved the Super Nintendo motherboard over 12 years, reducing the number of chips needed. Changes were mostly minor updates, with major generations like Classic, APU, 1-CHIP, and Junior. The final form, Super Nintendo Jr, had only nine chips and integrated components from the top and bottom parts.

title: Inside the Super Nintendo cartridges
author: fabiensanglard.net
summary: Super Nintendo cartridges had more than just game instructions and assets stored in ROM chips. The Super FX processor enhanced games like Starfox by allowing more sprites on screen. Various enhancement chips like SA-1 and GSU-1 were utilized to improve gameplay and graphics.

The text explains the advantages and disadvantages of each design choice and provides examples of systems that fall into different categories. Additionally, it emphasizes the importance of understanding these design choices in selecting the appropriate system for specific workloads.

title: A monorepo misconception - atomic cross-project commits
author: jsnell@iki.fi
summary:
In articles and discussions about monorepos, there's
one frequently alleged key benefit: atomic commits across the whole
tree let you make changes to both a library's implementation and the
clients in a single commit. Many authors even go as far to claim that
this is the only benefit of monorepos.


I like monorepos, but that particular claim makes no sense! It's not
how you'd actually make backwards incompatible changes, such as
interface refactorings, in a large monorepo. Instead the process would
be highly incremental, and more like the following:


Push one commit to change the library, such that it supports both
the old and new behavior with different interfaces.
Once you're sure the commit from stage 1 won't be reverted, push N
commits to switch each of the N clients to use the new interface.
Once you're sure the commits from stage 2 won't be reverted, push
one commit to remove the old implementation and interface from the
library.


There's a bunch of reasons why this is a nicer sequencing than a
single...

title: Web Environment Integrity vs. Private Access Tokens - They're the same thing!
author: jsnell@iki.fi
summary:
I've seen a lot of discussions in the last week about the Web
Environment Integrity proposal. Quite predictably from the moment
it got called things like "DRM for the web", people have
been arguing passionately against it on HN, Github issues, etc. The
basic claims seem to be that it's going to turn the web into a walled
garden, kill all small browsers, kill all small operating systems,
kill accessibility tools like screen readers, etc.


The Web Environment Integrity proposal is basically:


A website can request an attestation from the browser
The browser forwards the attestation requests to an attester
The attester checks properties like hardware and software integrity
If they check out, the attester creates a token and signs it with its private key.
The attester hands off the signed token to the browser, which in turn sends it to the website.
The website checks that the token was signed by a trusted attester


Here's a funny thing I suspect few of those commenters know: A
very similar mechanism already exis...

Visiting the office after a long period improved the author's well-being significantly, leading to increased productivity and a greater sense of belonging. title: Google SRE book
author: danluu.com
summary: The Google SRE book discusses key tenets of Site Reliability Engineering (SRE) teams, such as managing latency, performance, and capacity planning. It emphasizes the importance of error budgets and setting realistic expectations for service reliability. The book also addresses strategies to prevent and address cascading failures in complex systems.

title: Integer overflow checking cost
author: danluu.com
summary: How much overhead should we expect from enabling integer overflow checks?

title: Editing binaries
author: danluu.com
summary: Editing binaries is a trick that comes in handy a few times a year. You don't often need to, but when you do, there's no alternative.

title: Notes on Cruise's pedestrian accident
author: danluu.com
summary: The content is a set of notes summarizing the Quinn Emanuel report on Cruise's handling of an accident involving a Cruise autonomous vehicle (AV) and a pedestrian. The report highlights that Cruise failed to disclose that the AV dragged the pedestrian after the initial impact and that Cruise leadership focused on correcting the media narrative rather than providing complete information to regulators. The notes also provide a timeline of key events and details about the video footage of the accident.

title: Why it's impossible to agree on what's allowed
author: danluu.com
summary: Large platforms struggle to establish moderation policies that are universally accepted, even in trivial cases like "No Vehicles in the Park." This was demonstrated through a game created by David Turner, where people were asked to interpret a simple rule and make decisions based on it. Even in this case, there was no agreement on what should be allowed or not. Disagreements increase when dealing with charged issues, making it almost impossible for large platforms to satisfy user preferences and moderate content effectively.

title: Diseconomies of scale in fraud, spam, support, and moderation
author: danluu.com
summary: Facebook knew more about the negative effects of social media than it let on, including the spread of fake news. The company's engineers were applying company wisdom that "Done Is Better Than Perfect," leading to sloppy work and poor fact-checking. Facebook was slow to address hate speech and political manipulation on its platform, despite warnings from employees and external sources. The company's commitment to free expression was at odds with state repression and censorship, and its growth efforts were making integrity problems worse. Facebook's policies and incentives needed to change to address these issues.

title: How web bloat impacts users with slow devices
author: danluu.com
summary: In 2017, web bloat made the internet difficult to use for people without broadband speeds. Although bandwidth has increased exponentially, CPU performance for web apps hasn't scaled nearly as quickly, which makes it difficult for people with low-end devices even if they have high-end connections. Slow pages are often super-linearly slow as devices get slower, and slowness on one page doesn't strongly predict slowness on another page. Slow devices or any device with low bandwidth and/or poor connectivity work best when using lightweight, static pages that load a lot of content at once.

title: Files are hard
author: danluu.com
summary: Writing files in a way that ensures their robustness is challenging due to the complexity involved. The paper discusses various issues related to file corruption and data loss, such as crash consistency, filesystem semantics, filesystem correctness, error handling, and error recovery. It highlights the differences in how different filesystems handle errors and points out bugs and inconsistencies found in popular filesystems. The paper also addresses the frequency of disk errors and data corruption, emphasizing the need for caution when writing files and the importance of using libraries or tools to ensure safety. Overall, the document emphasizes the difficulty of reasoning about file-related problems and the need for careful considerations when working with filesystems.

title: I have risen
author: Yossi Kreinin
summary:
Hello to the readers still using RSS! I've moved the blog off WordPress to my own ugly publishing software, and will be
grateful if you report any glitches you see (posts or comments look bad on device X or feed reader Y, that sort of thing.)
This blog slowed down a lot in 2017, when I switched from a part-time programming position to a full-time senior management
position. Between the comment spam flood and the ancient pre-mobile design, it would take some doing to get the blog back into
shape; and between work and non-work stuff I had going, I didn't find time for said doing.
But I've gone back to programming a couple of years ago, and back to part-time a few months ago, and now the doing is done.
And do I have things to tell you!

title: refix: fast, debuggable, reproducible builds
author: Yossi Kreinin
summary: refix is a tool designed for fast, debuggable, and reproducible builds. It aims to make builds reproducible, debuggable, and fast by utilizing a small Rust program called refix to post-process build outputs, especially for C/C++ source code compiled to native binaries. By focusing on replacing ELF sections and handling executables, shared libraries, and object files, refix offers a faster and more widely applicable alternative to traditional methods like debugedit and sed. The tool addresses challenges developers face with finding source code in debugged programs and aims to streamline the debugging process without compromising reproducibility or speed.

title: Managers have no human rights
author: Yossi Kreinin
summary: Managers often face challenges without the same human rights as other employees in the workplace. The competitive nature of management roles can lead to adversarial relationships and a lack of psychological safety. Despite these difficulties, managers must navigate their roles with resilience and drive.

title: The state of AI for hand-drawn animation inbetweening
author: Yossi Kreinin
summary: The text discusses using AI to assist traditional hand-drawn animation workflows. It focuses on improving productivity by having AI take on tasks similar to a human assistant in animation. The goal is to enhance inbetweening processes, which involve creating frames between key animation frames for smoother motion.

title: A 100x speedup with unsafe Python
author: Yossi Kreinin
summary: The text discusses speeding up numpy code by 100x using "unsafe Python" techniques. By optimizing memory layout and using numpy arrays with default strides, cv2.resize can be significantly faster than other methods like pygame's smoothscale. The approach involves leveraging C-like knowledge to improve performance but comes with potential memory safety risks.

title: People can read their manager's mind
author: yosefk.com
summary: People generally don't do what they're told, but what they expect to be rewarded for. Managers often say they'll reward something ‚Äì perhaps they even believe it.

author: Writing - rachelbythebay
summary: The author encountered issues with an older Raspberry Pi due to a filesystem problem on the SD card, which caused remote logins to fail. The clock being over a day off prevented proper synchronization with NTP servers, affecting services like chrony and WireGuard. The author resolved the DNS resolution issue by adding secondary resolvers and configuring chrony to use a nearby host as a peer source for time synchronization.

title: Hitting every branch on the way down
author: Writing - rachelbythebay
summary: The author faced challenges with using autoconf and building on a BSD system, encountering issues with library versions and code formatting. They had to make adjustments like modifying the protobuf compiler output and adding missing #includes to make their code build successfully. Despite frustrations and obstacles, the author eventually resolved issues by finding a workaround for library dependencies and switching to a more compatible version of the protobuf library.

title: Reader feedback on autoconf and bugginess in general
author: Writing - rachelbythebay
summary: The author responds to reader feedback about using git log with "--full-history" and shares insights on finding the correct flags to display merge commits properly. They also discuss encountering technical issues while testing software and hardware, emphasizing the importance of addressing and fixing such problems within organizations. Additionally, the author reflects on the value of actively addressing and resolving engineering issues in a company's culture to ensure product excellence and customer satisfaction.

title: In Loving Memory of Square Checkbox
author: Nikita Prokopov
summary: The document titled "In Loving Memory of Square Checkbox" discusses the history and evolution of checkboxes and radio buttons in operating systems. It highlights the convention that checkboxes are square and radio buttons are round, which has been followed by major operating system vendors for decades. However, the introduction of the web and CSS led to the reinvention and redesign of these controls, with examples of checkboxes containing checkmarks and square radio buttons. Despite the chaos and temptation on the web, operating system vendors have mostly adhered to the convention. However, Apple has recently abandoned this tradition in their new visionOS by introducing round checkboxes. The document concludes by stating that the era of the square checkbox has come to an end.

title: JavaScript Bloat in 2024
author: Nikita Prokopov
summary: The author examined JavaScript bundle sizes of various websites in 2024. They found that even simple landing pages or static websites can have large JavaScript file sizes, with some exceeding 10 MB. The excessive JavaScript bloat raises concerns about browser performance and the balance between content and code size on the web.

title: Going to the cinema is a data visualization problem
author: Nikita Prokopov
summary: The text discusses creating a cinema selection website, allekinos.de, that shows every movie screening in Germany without ads or unnecessary features. The website allows users to filter screenings by various criteria and provides a simple, functional interface for easy navigation. The author emphasizes prioritizing user experience and transparency in displaying all available movie options.

title: Hardest Problem in Computer Science: Centering Things
author: Nikita Prokopov (niki@tonsky.me)
summary: The author argues that despite knowing how to center things using simple CSS properties, many applications still struggle with proper alignment, especially with fonts and icons. The key issues highlighted include font metrics, line height challenges, and the difficulty of aligning icons next to text. Solutions proposed involve setting font metrics correctly, using image formats for icons instead of fonts, and paying attention to manual compensations for precise alignment.

title: Humble Chronicles: The Inescapable Objects
author: Nikita Prokopov (niki@tonsky.me)
summary: The text discusses the implementation of object-oriented programming (OOP) concepts in the design of HumbleUI for managing state and behavior in components like Nodes. It explores the benefits of OOP-like structures for code reuse, partial code replacement, and future-proofing by defining protocols, parent classes, and concrete types in Clojure. The author reflects on how OOP principles, originally developed for UI design, continue to be relevant and useful for managing complex software systems.

title: Humble Chronicles: Shape of the Component
author: Nikita Prokopov (niki@tonsky.me)
summary: The text discusses the process of defining and using components in Humble UI, emphasizing the importance of clear structure and lifecycle management. It introduces concepts like using signals for state management and creating reusable components for easy code sharing. The author also touches on the idea of simplifying component reuse by breaking down complex elements into smaller, reusable parts.

title: Going to the cinema is a data visualization problem
author: Nikita Prokopov (niki@tonsky.me)
summary: The author created a simple cinema selection website called allekinos.de that shows all movie screenings across Germany. The website focuses on functionality over design, allowing users to filter screenings by various criteria. The author used DataScript for data management and application.garden for hosting the website efficiently.

title: Why Must Systems Be Operated?
author: Marc Brooker
summary: The text discusses the importance of understanding the behavior of systems, such as RAID and load balancers, to prevent failures caused by various factors like latent issues and triggered failures. It emphasizes the need for continuous maintenance and a deep understanding of system complexities to ensure durability and availability. Automation can help in maintaining systems, but it is crucial to recognize that automation becomes an integral part of the system and requires proper attention.

title: The Builder's Guide to Better Mousetraps
author: marcbrooker@gmail.com (Marc Brooker)
summary: Marc Brooker, an engineer at Amazon Web Services, shares advice on innovation and decision-making when considering building something new instead of using existing solutions. He discusses the importance of evaluating costs and benefits, considering opportunity costs, assessing long-term ownership implications, and determining if the problem being solved is simpler, different, or at a different scale than existing solutions. Brooker emphasizes the need to understand the technical risks, milestones for success, and the potential distractions building something new may pose. He suggests seeking input from trusted colleagues to validate conclusions before proceeding with the decision to build.

title: Finding Needles in a Haystack with Best-of-K
author: marcbrooker@gmail.com (Marc Brooker)
summary: The text discusses the use of best-of-k algorithms for load balancing in distributed systems, particularly focusing on the challenges when the bins have limited size capacities. The best-of-k approach involves selecting k workers out of n and sending a request to the least loaded worker among those k. The text also addresses the issue of capacity limits for workers and proposes an iterative variant to handle rejections when all selected workers are at capacity. It further delves into the theoretical analysis of the best-of-k algorithm's performance in different scenarios, emphasizing that while best-of-k is powerful, it is not a one-size-fits-all solution and may require different approaches for specific challenges like finding workers with free capacity slots.

title: Formal Methods: Just Good Engineering Practice?
author: marcbrooker@gmail.com (Marc Brooker)
summary: Formal methods are an important part of good software engineering practice, especially for large-scale and critical systems. Using formal design work can speed up software development by reducing rework and improving system optimization. Different types of software may benefit from varying engineering approaches, with formal methods being particularly valuable for systems with well-understood requirements.

title: It's always TCP_NODELAY. Every damn time.
author: marcbrooker@gmail.com (Marc Brooker)
summary: The author discusses the importance of enabling TCP_NODELAY to improve latency in distributed systems. Nagle's algorithm, which aims to optimize TCP headers, may not be necessary in modern systems. Enabling TCP_NODELAY is recommended for latency-sensitive distributed systems on current hardware.

title: The power of two random choices
author: Marc Brooker

title: Weird Python Integers Part II: Constants in Bytecode
author: Kate Murphy
summary:
This is a quick follow-up to Weird Python Integers. While writing that post, I saw some Python behaviour I didn‚Äôt understand. Then I read some comments by kmill and squeaky-clean in response to my original post, and now I can explain Python‚Äôs behaviour.
If you don‚Äôt know about the ‚Äúsmall integers‚Äù table in Python, I recommend reading the original post first or this might be confusing.

Given the small integers table, these lines make sense to me:
>>> 100 is 100
True
>>> (10 ** 2) is (10 ** 2)
True


100 is in the small integers table
(10 ** 2) is evaluated to 100 which is the same number in the small integers table.

Even these lines make sense:
>>> x = 1000
>>> y = 1000
>>> x is y
False
>>> (10 ** 3) is (10 ** 3)
False

Both x and y are too large to be in the small integers table, so they are not the same object.
However, this did not make sense to me:
>>> 1000 is 1000
True

Figuring it out with dis
Clearly something different is happening for 1000 is 1000 vs. (100 ** 2) is (100 ** 2). I‚Äôm not familiar with Pyt...

title: Strange Hash Instances in Ruby
author: Kate Murphy
summary:
Note: All code was run using Ruby MRI 2.4.1 and is not guaranteed to behave the same in other implementations (JRuby, mruby, etc). Also you probably don‚Äôt want to do this in a real project.

Like (every?) user of Ruby I constantly use the built-in Hash class. I‚Äôve made my own classes usable as keys and know that there are multiple equality methods. With this understanding I decided to try and make strange Hash instances.
Strange Hash #1: Non-unique keys
How about a hash that only allows one value for any Integer key regardless of the integer value? From the documentation it seems that this is as simple as changing Integer#hash to always return the same value and Integer#eql? to always return true:
class Integer
   def eql?(other)
     true
   end

  def hash
     0
  end
end

table = {}
table[1] = 'one'
table[5] = 'five'
puts table
#=> {1=>"one", 5=>"five"}

Strange, that wasn‚Äôt what I expected. The table has entries for both 1 and 5 even though I don‚Äôt expect Hash to be able to differentiate these keys anymore....

title: Exploding Git Repositories
author: Kate Murphy
summary:
If you are an adventurous sort (and can handle a potential reboot) I invite you to clone this tiny repo:
$ git clone https://github.com/Katee/git-bomb.git

Were you able to clone it? Unless you have quite a lot of memory (both RAM and storage) git was killed, ran out of memory, or you had to reboot. Why is this? It is a perfectly formed repo made of only 12 objects.
How does a tiny repo cause git to run out of memory? The secret is that git de-duplicates ‚Äúblobs‚Äù (which are used to store files) to make repositories smaller and allow using the same blob when a file remains unchanged between commits. Git also allows de-duplication of ‚Äútree‚Äù objects (which define the directory structure in a repository). git-bomb tries to make a billion files, however it only has 10 references to the file blob and only has 10 tree objects in all.
This is extremely similar to the ‚Äúbillion laughs‚Äù (aka ‚ÄúXML bomb‚Äù) hence the name ‚Äúgit bomb‚Äù.
Structure
Bottom



At the bottom there is a file blob containing ‚Äúone laugh‚Äù:
$ git show 5faa3...

title: Making Your Own Git Bombs
author: Kate Murphy
summary:
Note: This is all Python 3 code. Other versions of Python may handle subprocesses and bytearrays differently.
A Git bomb is a compact repository that explodes to consume extreme size on disk and in memory. Read more about them in the original git bomb post. This post walks through some code to create them. A full script to create them is available in the Git Bomb Readme.
The basic outline:
depth = 10  # how many layers deep
width = 10  # how many files or folders per depth level
blob_body = b'one laugh'  # content of blob at bottom

# Create base blob
blob_hash = write_git_object(blob_body, type='blob')

# Dirs is an array of (name, hash) pairs
dirs = [('f' + str(i), blob_hash) for i in range(width)]
file_permission = '100644'
# Write tree object containing the blob `width` times
tree_hash = write_git_object(create_tree(dirs, file_permission), type='tree')

# Make layers of tree objects using the previous tree object
# Each tree contains the last tree `width` times
for i in range(depth - 1):
    # again dirs is ...

title: Simple Hash Collisions in Lua
author: Kate Murphy
summary:
After investigating the CRuby source code for hash tables, my interest was piqued, and I decided to look into another hash table implementation before leaving Recurse Center. I chose to investigate Lua because the hash table is the central abstraction of the language. I don‚Äôt actually know Lua, but luckily I spent most of my investigation in a debugger or C source code.
One of the first things that jumped out at me was that there didn‚Äôt seem to be any mention of siphash in the Lua source code. Ruby and Python use siphash with a per-session key to generate hashes. You can easily verify that the hash of a string changes in different Ruby sessions:
$ irb
irb(main):001:0> "hello!".hash
=> -3270480275822396260
irb(main):002:0> exit
$ irb
irb(main):001:0> "hello!".hash
=> -4583553666733776547

Using a debugger, I saw that strings in Lua also have different hashes between different sessions. However, Lua doesn‚Äôt appear to use siphash, so I decided to investigate exactly what it does instead. The Lua hashing approach fo...

title: SUBLIME
Why Don‚Äôt We Just Ban Targeted Advertising?
author: Gilad Edelman
summary: Policy makers have focused on pressuring social media companies to improve their practices, like fact-checking and content moderation. content: But won‚Äôt this put social media platforms out of business, you may ask? No, not at all! There was advertising long before targeting, and there would still be advertising in a world in which targeting individual users, children or otherwise, were eliminated.

According to a study released last year by the Harvard T.H. Chan School of Public Health, in 2022 Facebook, Instagram, Snapchat, TikTok, Twitter, and YouTube made a combined $11 billion in advertising revenue from ads targeted to users younger than 18.
Wow. Well put.
To boil it down: Time equals data equals profits for everyone from Facebook to TikTok to YouTube (which, remember, is owned by Google).

As RJ Cross at the Public Interest Research Group put it, ‚Äúit‚Äôs a feedback loop of getting people as addicted to their devices as possible so you can extract data about them so you can sell them stuff.‚Äù

title: CircuitBreaker
author: Martin Fowler
summary: CircuitBreaker is a pattern used in software systems to prevent cascading failures caused by remote calls that fail or hang. The basic idea is to wrap a protected function call in a circuit breaker object that monitors for failures. Once the failures reach a certain threshold, the circuit breaker trips and all further calls return with an error. The circuit breaker can also detect when the underlying calls are working again and reset itself. This pattern is useful in situations where you want to protect parts of a system from failures in other parts, and it can be implemented in various programming languages.

In 1919, in the city of Padua, brothers Luigi and Silvio Barbieri created Aperol, now the most famous Spritz bitter, from orange peel, herbs and spices. Due to its low alcohol volume (11% ABV), Aperol was initially marketed towards health-conscious drinkers and women (its slogan in the ‚Äò30s was ‚ÄúSignora! Aperol keeps you thin"). However, by the ‚Äò80s, it had been firmly integrated into aperitivo culture ‚Äî the Italian tradition of having refreshments in the post-work, pre-dinner period ‚Äî throughout the Veneto region.

content: wow. ok this is really nailing that in for me then...

We normally think about sleep health as ‚Äúgetting 7 to 9 hours of sleep a night,‚Äù but more and more we‚Äôre realizing that we need to care about when those hours of sleep happen. In that last study, sleep regularity was found to be a better predictor of mortality than sleep duration, while another study looking at factors that predict mortality in older men found sleep rhythmicity to be the highest ranking sleep-related factor, ranking fifth. Sleep duration, on the other hand, only showed up about 18 spots further down the list. Does this mean sleep duration doesn‚Äôt matter? Of course not. Does it mean we need a definition of sleep health that includes regularity and rhythmicity? Sure seems that way.
I really am getting this dialed in now that I'm being realistic about what time to wake up. this week has been off though...

Scale up a single night with too much light to a lifetime‚Äôs worth of light at night and you start to understand why people with higher sleep regularity (and more consistent light exposure) have a ‚Äú20 percent to 48 percent lower risk of all-cause mortality, a 16 percent to 39 percent lower risk of cancer mortality, and a 22 percent to 57 percent lower risk of cardiometabolic mortality‚Äù than people in the most irregular sleep cohort. Regular sleep means your brain‚Äôs more confident about what time it is. Irregular sleep makes it lose confidence, which throws off rhythms all throughout your body.
hmmm. this makes me really want to try to make my light setup a reality.

One big difference between societies without artificial light and how we live now is (surprise, surprise) they get way less light at night than we do. This has ramifications for our body‚Äôs natural production of melatonin, which gets squashed in the presence of light. In 2020, researchers reported that nearly half of typical homes had evening light levels that would be bright enough to suppress natural melatonin production by 50 percent.
wow. this is fascinating. i'm curious how much sleep debt i've got right now...

What happens if you put people who‚Äôve been sleeping 7 to 8 hours a night in total darkness for 14 hours a day for a month? Answer: The first night, they sleep a long time ‚Äî close to 12 hours. The next night, they sleep about 10-ish hours, then 9.5-ish, then after a week it‚Äôs down to 9 hours, before eventually leveling out close to 8 hours near the end of the month of long nights. You can think of this gradual drop-off in sleep duration as capturing a washing-out of sleep debt. And if people sleeping 7 to 8 hours a night had sleep to catch up on, surely the rest of us are doomed. Ah, if only modern life weren‚Äôt ruining things for us, we‚Äôd all be sleeping the long, long sleeps we‚Äôre designed for.

content: The most effective mechanism I‚Äôve found for rolling out No Wrong Door is initiating three-way conversations when asked questions.
Now the product engineer gets support from the same two folks as before, but because they‚Äôre helping the product engineer navigate the process, they get to a better situation.
This has changed my mind on some recent interactions.

Something I‚Äôve been thinking about recently is how engineering organizations can adopt a variant of the No Wrong Doors policy to directly connect folks with problems with the right team and information. Then the first contact point becomes a support system for navigating the bureaucracy successfully.

After they find the right team, they are forced to figure out how the SRE Observability team records when a checklist is completed. In almost all cases, the product engineer ends up frustrated, but it‚Äôs not just them.

Some governmental agencies have started to adopt No Wrong Door policies, which aim to provide help‚Äìoften health or mental health services‚Äìto individuals even if they show up to the wrong agency to request help. The core insight is that the employees at those agencies are far better equipped to navigate their own bureaucracies than an individual who knows nothing about the bureaucracy‚Äôs internal function.

title: The Chinese and the Iron Road
author: Stanford University Press
summary:
The completion of the transcontinental railroad in May 1869 is usually told as a story of national triumph and a key moment for American Manifest Destiny. The Railroad made it possible to cross the country in a matter of days instead of months, paved the way for new settlers to come out west, and helped speed America's entry onto the world stage as a modern nation that spanned a full continent. It also created vast wealth for its four owners, including the fortune with which Leland Stanford would found Stanford University some two decades later. But while the Transcontinental has often been celebrated in national memory, little attention has been paid to the Chinese workers who made up 90 percent of the workforce on the Western portion of the line. The Railroad could not have been built without Chinese labor, but the lives of Chinese railroad workers themselves have been little understood and largely invisible.

This landmark volume explores the experiences of Chinese railroad workers and their place in cultural...

On the return trip, Scott, still insisting on a level of ‚Äúinhuman exertion,‚Äù and the rest of his team got frostbite and froze to death. Amundsen‚Äôs crew completed the 1400-mile trip home without issue, maintaining their 15-miles-per-day pace.

‚ÄúGoing and surface as good as ever,‚Äù Amundsen journaled. ‚ÄúWeather splendid‚Äîcalm with sunshine.‚Äù They could have made it to the Pole that day, but ‚ÄúAmundsen would not allow the daily fifteen miles to be exceeded,‚Äù Roland Huntford writes in The Last Place on Earth
One hundred shots on net. Two hundred lines of code on your commute. Three hundred words on your lunch break.
It doesn‚Äôt matter how ambitious or speculative the goal, you get there by taking one small step after one small step.‚Äù

‚ÄúIf you consistently maintain even just a little bit of energy in one direction, it's incredible what you can deflect over time.‚Äù Writing just a little bit during his spare time, ‚ÄúI accumulated a lot of words, and in a five or six year period, I wrote about 15 novels,‚Äù which sold well over time that ‚ÄúI now have the luxury of writing full-time.‚Äù

Every day, ‚ÄúI wrote in the morning before work and on my lunch break.‚Äù It was a small change, but ‚Äúit‚Äôs like a meteor heading towards the Earth,‚Äù Hugh said. ‚ÄúYou don‚Äôt need to blow it up. You just need to send a rocket up there to slightly nudge it in a different direction.‚Äù

‚ÄúOften,‚Äù Hugh said, ‚Äúthe feeling that we can‚Äôt break our stasis and launch our lives in a different direction is really due to the feeling that we should have done it five or ten or twenty years ago.‚Äù

content: What we have today is a centrally-planned economy by MBA sociopaths, operated as a looting ground for the rich.

Competitors that make better software won‚Äôt be able to grow unless they get past the gatekeepers. Software that‚Äôs outright awful will still succeed because it genuinely doesn‚Äôt matter whether Microsoft, Google, Adobe, or Apple products actually work.

If you think companies are going to pay ‚ÄúAI‚Äù wranglers senior-level pay in the long term, or that they‚Äôre going to pay for the time it takes to rewrite or properly comprehend the code being generated, then you‚Äôre missing the point of why employers are adopting the technology.
God this is dystopian
Not content with removing CSS and HTML almost entirely from the job market, we‚Äôre now shifting towards the model where devs are instead ‚ÄúAI‚Äù wranglers.

Especially considering that a junior specialist often has the same capabilities in their field as a senior generalist, which means a whole host of previously intractable technical problems suddenly become tractable when your teams are composed of cross-functional specialists.

Cross-functional teams of specialists are almost certainly much more productive than a team that consists of identikit full-stack developers and a mostly untrained PM who lives in a constant state of anxiety and panic.

Once you understand this, it becomes obvious why Tailwind is so popular among developers: Tailwind provides a loose approximation of the experience you would get from having a dedicated CSS expert on board. ‚ÄúHere are some classes and attribute hooks. Just use them in your markup and everything will look great. Of course I‚Äôve also written documentation for you. What do you take me for?"
Yeah the stress of the industry is kind of wild. People are gone all the time.

We‚Äôre made to do all this while watching our peers lose their jobs, our employers savage society through pervasive surveillance and collaboration with authoritarian companies, and our data centres suck up the entire water supply for entire municipalities.
Dang I‚Äôm not old enough to have experienced this yet.

The same applies to my skills in Svelte. I first got into Svelte with version 3. They‚Äôre now releasing version 5 and are completely changing their approach to state management. My old Svelte skills are obsolete but they‚Äôre still there, useless and cluttering up my memory.

The framework knowledge itself is also perishable. Not because your memory or physical coordination deteriorates (though that happens too), but because frameworks change more and faster than the underlying platform.

content:
When I heard the released demo, I was shocked, angered and in
disbelief that Mr. Altman would pursue a voice that sounded so
eerily similar to mine that my closest friends and news outlets
could not tell the difference.

Last September, I received an offer from Sam Altman, who wanted to
hire me to voice the current ChatGPT 4.0 system. He told me that
he felt that by my voicing the system, I could bridge the gap
between tech companies and creatives and help consumers to feel
comfortable with the seismic shift concerning humans and AI. He
said he felt that my voice would be comforting to people.
After much consideration and for personal reasons, I declined the
offer.

content: I‚Äôm upset that no one thought that if this ordinance was put in place, the first thing that would happen was that everyone would raise their prices. From a driver standpoint, from a restaurant standpoint, and from a third-party delivery standpoint, everyone‚Äôs losing money right now.

‚ÄúDeliveries have been about 40 percent of our business since we opened in 2018. And since the ordinance went into effect and the fees were raised, we‚Äôve seen at least a 30 to 40 percent drop on that business. So that comes out to an 11 percent drop on the overall business versus last year.

Some Seattle delivery drivers, whom the law intended to help, have said they lost money overall due to fewer orders being placed. Nationwide, in cities like New York and LA that have passed similar ordinances, restaurants and delivery drivers have seen the same effects.

Like many other eateries in the city, Spice Waala suffered a hit to its business when a City Council ordinance raising the minimum wage for app delivery drivers came into effect earlier this year. DoorDash and Uber Eats responded by adding a $5 fee to all deliveries, and order volume dropped as customers rebelled against the higher prices.

The author highlights the benefits of using a GUI over raw ChatGPT, including a prescriptive workflow, direct manipulation affordances, and easier sharing of the tool.
