Thus only a very small number of companies (currently TSMC, Samsung, and Intel) attempt to operate leading-edge nodes, and the industry has shifted to a ‚Äúfabless‚Äù model where companies like Apple and Nvidia design their chips but have them manufactured by ‚Äúfoundries‚Äù like TSMC.

Larger wafers require more expensive equipment. The switch to 300 mm wafers, for instance, necessitated much greater use of automated material handling equipment, as the wafers were too heavy to carry around in FOUPs by hand. These handling systems, in turn, required larger structures with taller cleanroom ceilings.

Roughly 70-80% of the cost of a new fab will be the process tools that go in it. (One side effect of this is that upgrading an existing fab to use a more advanced process node can cost an appreciable fraction of the cost of a totally new fab.)

Despite their size and complexity, fabs are built surprisingly quickly, around two to four years on average. This is not all that different from other large commercial building projects, and far faster than some other tightly controlled process facilities, like nuclear power plants.
Tools must be handled carefully: the sensitivity of production tools means that a dropped or bumped piece of equipment can result in delays and millions of dollars of repair.
In some cases this has meant things like using equipment to ‚Äúeat‚Äù welding smoke, and painting the edges of anything cut on-site with epoxy paint to prevent particle emissions.
Putting this material in place at the necessary level of precision requires thousands of specially trained construction workers.
All this equipment and processes consume large amounts of energy. A large fab might demand 100 megawatts of energy, or 10% of the capacity of a large nuclear reactor.
How did I not know about this. Wildly cool.

A fab uses nitrogen and oxygen in such large amounts (a large logic fab might use 50,000 cubic meters of nitrogen every hour) that fabs will often have air separation plants on-site that produce gasses like nitrogen, oxygen and argon.

Achieving this means that sub-fab equipment must be manufactured with much more stringent requirements and much tighter tolerances than in conventional manufacturing. Things like pipes, ducts, pumps, and other material handling equipment are stainless steel and teflon-coated. The interior of pipes must be electropolished to prevent particles from being emitted or providing places for contaminants to accumulate, and pipes must be joined using special orbital welding methods to prevent leaks or contamination.

To prevent byproducts (particularly ammonia) from reacting with each other, several separate exhaust systems must be used. Many of the processes require abatement equipment (which will burn off any harmful byproducts) or scrubbers to remove hazardous material.

title: Sand Won't Save You This Time
author: Derek Lowe
summary: In a comment to my post on putting out fires last week, one commenter mentioned the utility of the good old sand bucket, and wondered if there was anything that would go on to set the sand on fire.

content: The volume of chemicals and gasses used, and the amount of exhaust generated, requires an enormous amount of piping, with some pipes reaching up to ten feet in diameter. And these chemicals must be extremely pure, in some cases 99.9999999% pure.
Anti-static materials must be used for things like flooring to prevent the buildup of static electricity.

title: Here‚Äôs how TSMC protects itself from earthquakes
author: Adam Conway
summary: Following a tragic earthquake in Taiwan, we looked into how TSMC protects itself from earthquakes in a place that's prone to them.

content: Some extremely sensitive equipment, such as lithography tools, might require even more stringent measures like active vibration dampers that can sense and cancel out any rogue vibrations.

The extreme precision required means process tools are extremely sensitive to vibration (even loud noises can negatively affect the manufacturing process), and fabs are designed to minimize it. Fabs are typically built away from airports, rail lines, busy highways, and any other significant outside source of vibrations, and the fab supporting facilities themselves must also be designed to eliminate vibrations.

The large number of manufacturing steps means that it can take months for a wafer to go through the entire process. This, combined with the large number of wafers a fab produces a month, means that at any given time there are tens of thousands of wafers at various points in the production process, traveling back and forth between tools or being stored waiting for their turn.
This is the type of innovation in most curious about.

. This TSMC fab, for instance, was built with a Class 100 cleanroom, but the wafers themselves are handled inside Class 0.1 ‚Äúmini-environments.‚Äù By adopting the mini-environment strategy, fabs have been able remove even more impurities from the air without having to purify the millions of cubic feet of air in the cleanroom.
How do they do this??
In addition to these large HVAC systems, the materials and process tools used in the cleanroom need to be specially designed not to emit particles.

To prevent particles outside the cleanroom from entering, the cleanroom is kept at positive pressure relative to the outside. Keeping the air at the level of cleanliness required means the air is being changed hundreds of times per hour, compared to the 5-10 times per hour in a typical office building.
Man i didnt even think about that‚Ä¶
HVAC systems will similarly be isolated between different process zones.

title: EUV lithography systems
author: asml.com
summary: ASML's EUV lithography systems use extreme ultraviolet light to create high-resolution microchips for advanced devices. EUV technology supports Moore's Law by enabling the production of smaller, more powerful transistors. These systems drive innovation in chip manufacturing and make mass production of cutting-edge microchips affordable.

content: Below the cleanroom is the sub-fab, one or more levels (typically two) that contain the ducts, piping, wiring, and equipment needed to support the cleanroom operations.
To combat this, Intel instituted a process known as Copy EXACTLY! New fabs would be identical to existing fabs to the extent possible, right down to the color and brand of the paint on the walls.

When semiconductors were being researched at Bell Labs in the 1940s, mysterious component failures were eventually traced to researchers who had touched copper door knobs; the tiny number of copper atoms that migrated from the door the workers hands was enough to ruin their work material. Early semiconductor manufacturers found that their processes were influenced by, among other things, the phase of the moon, whether workers had recently visited the bathroom, and female workers‚Äô menstrual cycles.
I can barely wrap my head around this.
How many do they throw out per day? Do they recycle?
A few atoms in the wrong place can cause a process step to fail. Imperceptibly small amounts of impurities can irreparably damage materials.

With most manufacturing processes, even those using precision methods to produce interchangeable parts, there is a fair degree of tolerance in the process. If a part is a fraction of a millimeter too long or too short, it will still fit. If the impurity content of a metal is a tiny bit too high, the metal can still be used.
How do we have this knowledge captured and saved? Could we rebuild them from scratch?

Early integrated circuits could be made with just five to ten different masks and dozens of process steps, but a modern leading-edge microchip might require 80 or more masks and thousands of separate process steps.

title: Metrology Primer
author: Doug O'Laughlin
summary: Metrology and inspection are crucial steps in semiconductor manufacturing for measuring quality. These processes involve using various technologies to ensure correct dimensions and detect defects. Advanced packaging and increasing semiconductor complexity are driving the demand for metrology and inspection.

content: One key supporting process is polishing: because a microchip is built up from dozens of individual layers, variations in layer thickness will propagate over time as more layers are added, causing problems if left unaddressed.
Ok this is so cool. Might be my favorite process.

The light that isn‚Äôt blocked by the mask passes through and induces a chemical reaction in the photoresist; with positive photoresist, the area exposed to light weakens and becomes soluble; with negative photoresist, the exposed area hardens while the rest of the photoresist remains soluble.

title: Atomic Layer Deposition
author: asm.com
summary: Atomic Layer Deposition, or ALD, is one of our technological solutions that works at a tiny level to make a huge difference. Learn all about it.

content: Current common layering methods include thermal oxidation (exposing wafers to oxygen in a furnace, which creates a thin layer of silicon dioxide on the wafer surface), chemical vapor deposition (CVD) (where gaseous chemicals are brought together, depositing their reactants on the surface of the wafer) and sputtering (where a solid material is bombarded with plasma ions, causing atoms to break free and be deposited on the wafer‚Äôs surface).
Ooo so maybe there‚Äôs a cheaper process?

This fabrication method is known as the planar process, and it was invented at Fairchild Semiconductor in 1959 by Jean Hoerni. It‚Äôs what makes integrated circuits, and modern computer technology, possible.

Because of the enormous number of components in a modern electronic chip, this wiring must be routed on separate layers, which are separated by electrical insulators known as dielectrics. Intel‚Äôs current process, for instance, consists of 15 layers of metal wiring.

Materials are placed in layers a few atoms thin. Creating objects this small requires ultra-precise manufacturing equipment, and a production environment that can screen out as many sources of interference as possible; every rogue speck of dust or tiny fluctuation in electrical voltage.

Moore‚Äôs Law, the observation that the number of components on an integrated circuit tends to double every two years. (There is a Moore‚Äôs Second Law, also known as Rock‚Äôs Law, which posits that the cost of a semiconductor fab doubles every four years.)
The billion here is hard to fathom.

In the late 60s and early 70s, a semiconductor fabrication facility (or ‚Äòfab‚Äô) cost on the order of $4 million (~$31 million in 2024 dollars). Today, a modern fab can cost $10-$20 billion or more.
This is insane‚Ä¶

Today, an AMD Ryzen processor with 9.9 billion transistors is on sale for $650, or about $0.000000066 per transistor; in other words, since the 1950s the cost of a transistor has fallen by about a factor of 300 million.

content: The method that gives me the most confidence that my UI logic is good to go is not system tests, but human tests. Literally clicking around in a real browser by hand. Because half the time UI testing is not just about "does it work" but also "does it feel right". No automation can tell you that.

The end-to-end'ness has a tendency to catch not problems with the domain model or business logic, but some configuration or interaction that's preventing the system from loading correctly at all. Catching that early and cheaply is good.

Which gets to the heart of why we automate testing. We do it for the quick feedback loop on changes, we do it to catch regressions, but most of all, we do it to become confident that the system works. These are all valid goals, but that doesn't mean system testing is the best way to fulfill them.

content: Pages with rote, algorithmic responses should be a red flag. Unwillingness on the part of your team to automate such pages implies that the team lacks confidence that they can clean up their technical debt. This is a major problem worth escalating.

This kind of tension is common within a team, and often reflects an underlying mistrust of the team‚Äôs self-discipline: while some team members want to implement a ‚Äúhack‚Äù to allow time for a proper fix, others worry that a hack will be forgotten or that the proper fix will be deprioritized indefinitely. This concern is credible, as it‚Äôs easy to build layers of unmaintainable technical debt by patching over problems instead of making real fixes.

This strategy gave us enough breathing room to actually fix the longer-term problems in Bigtable and the lower layers of the storage stack, rather than constantly fixing tactical problems. On-call engineers could actually accomplish work when they weren‚Äôt being kept up by pages at all hours. Ultimately, temporarily backing off on our alerts allowed us to make faster progress toward a better service.
Distributing the histogram boundaries approximately exponentially (in this case by factors of roughly 3) is often an easy way to visualize the distribution of your requests.

When building a monitoring system from scratch, it‚Äôs tempting to design a system based upon the mean of some quantity: the mean latency, the mean CPU usage of your nodes, or the mean fullness of your databases. The danger presented by the latter two cases is obvious: CPUs and databases can easily be utilized in a very imbalanced way.

For example, an HTTP 500 error triggered due to loss of connection to a database or other critical backend might be served very quickly; however, as an HTTP 500 error indicates a failed request, factoring 500s into your overall latency might result in misleading calculations. On the other hand, a slow error is even worse than a fast error! Therefore, it‚Äôs important to track error latency, as opposed to just filtering out errors.

The simplest way to think about black-box monitoring versus white-box monitoring is that black-box monitoring is symptom-oriented and represents active‚Äînot predicted‚Äîproblems: "The system isn‚Äôt working correctly, right now." White-box monitoring depends on the ability to inspect the innards of the system, such as logs or HTTP endpoints, with instrumentation. White-box monitoring therefore allows detection of imminent problems, failures masked by retries, and so forth.

In general, Google has trended toward simpler and faster monitoring systems, with better tools for post hoc analysis. We avoid "magic" systems that try to learn thresholds or automatically detect causality. Rules that detect unexpected changes in end-user request rates are one counterexample; while these rules are still kept as simple as possible, they give a very quick detection of a very simple, specific, severe anomaly.

(That being said, while it can be fun to have access to traffic graph dashboards and the like, SRE teams carefully avoid any situation that requires someone to ‚Äústare at a screen to watch for problems.‚Äù)

Paging a human is a quite expensive use of an employee‚Äôs time. If an employee is at work, a page interrupts their workflow. If the employee is at home, a page interrupts their personal time, and perhaps even their sleep. When pages occur too frequently, employees second-guess, skim, or even ignore incoming alerts, sometimes even ignoring a "real" page that‚Äôs masked by the noise. Outages can be prolonged because other noise interferes with a rapid diagnosis and fix. Effective alerting systems have good signal and very low noise.

content: The Internet is changing that. Anyone can publish an essay on the Web, and it gets judged, as any writing should, by what it says, not who wrote it. Who are you to write about x? You are whatever you wrote.
Above all, make a habit of paying attention to things you're not supposed to, either because they're "inappropriate," or not important, or not what you're supposed to be working on.
History seems to me so important that it's misleading to treat it as a mere field of study. Another way to describe it is all the data we have so far.
This is right up my alley

One of the keys to coolness is to avoid situations where inexperience may make you look foolish. If you want to find surprises you should do the opposite. Study lots of different things, because some of the most interesting surprises are unexpected connections between different fields. For example, jam, bacon, pickles, and cheese, which are among the most pleasing of foods, were all originally intended as methods of preservation. And so were books and paintings.

I write down things that surprise me in notebooks. I never actually get around to reading them and using what I've written, but I do tend to reproduce the same thoughts later. So the main value of notebooks may be what writing things down leaves in your head.
have a hunch you want to pay attention not just to things that seem wrong, but things that seem wrong in a humorous way.

For example, everyone I've talked to while writing this essay felt the same about English classes-- that the whole process seemed pointless. But none of us had the balls at the time to hypothesize that it was, in fact, all a mistake. We all thought there was just something we weren't getting.

find it especially useful to ask why about things that seem wrong. For example, why should there be a connection between humor and misfortune? Why do we find it funny when a character, even one we like, slips on a banana peel? There's a whole essay's worth of surprises there for sure.

Collecting surprises is a similar process. The more anomalies you've seen, the more easily you'll notice new ones. Which means, oddly enough, that as you grow older, life should become more and more surprising.

Once you remember that Normans conquered England in 1066, it will catch your attention when you hear that other Normans conquered southern Italy at about the same time. Which will make you wonder about Normandy, and take note when a third book mentions that Normans were not, like most of what is now called France, tribes that flowed in as the Roman empire collapsed, but Vikings (norman = north man) who arrived four centuries later in 911.

And the difference in the way fathers and mothers bought ice cream for their kids: the fathers like benevolent kings bestowing largesse, the mothers harried, giving in to pressure. So, yes, there does seem to be some material even in fast food.
You should only write about things you've thought about a lot. And anything you come across that surprises you, who've thought about the topic a lot, will probably surprise most readers.
And so they're the most valuable sort of fact you can get. They're like a food that's not merely healthy, but counteracts the unhealthy effects of things you've already eaten.
And I found the best way to get information out of them was to ask what surprised them. How was the place different from what they expected?

So what's interesting? For me, interesting means surprise. Interfaces, as Geoffrey James has said, should follow the principle of least astonishment. A button that looks like it will make a machine stop should make it stop, not speed up. Essays should do the opposite. Essays should aim for maximum surprise.
The river's algorithm is simple. At each step, flow down. For the essayist this translates to: flow interesting. Of all the places to go next, choose the most interesting.

They don't always, of course. Sometimes you start with a promising question and get nowhere. But those you don't publish. Those are like experiments that get inconclusive results. An essay you publish ought to tell the reader something he didn't already know.

Outside writers tend to supply editorials of the defend-a-position variety, which make a beeline toward a rousing (and foreordained) conclusion. But the staff writers feel obliged to write something "balanced." Since they're writing for a popular magazine, they start with the most radioactively controversial questions, from which-- because they're writing for a popular magazine-- they then proceed to recoil in terror.
I relate Ôøºso deeply

So it does matter to have an audience. The things I've written just for myself are no good. They tend to peter out. When I run into difficulties, I find I conclude with a few vague questions and then drift off to get a cup of tea.

Figure out what? You don't know yet. And so you can't begin with a thesis, because you don't have one, and may never have one. An essay doesn't begin with a statement, but with a question. In a real essay, you don't take a position and defend it. You notice a door that's ajar, and you open it and walk in to see what's inside.
Essayer is the French verb meaning "to try" and an essai is an attempt. An essay is something you write to try to figure something out.

More often than not I have to change what I was saying as well. But the aim is never to be convincing per se. As the reader gets smarter, convincing and true become identical, so if I can convince smart readers I must be near the truth.

And yet this principle is built into the very structure of the things they teach you to write in high school. The topic sentence is your thesis, chosen in advance, the supporting paragraphs the blows you strike in the conflict, and the conclusion-- uh, what is the conclusion? I was never sure about that in high school. It seemed as if we were just supposed to restate what we said in the first paragraph, but in different enough words that no one could tell. Why bother? But when you understand the origins of this sort of "essay," you can see where the conclusion comes from. It's the concluding remarks to the jury.

It's often mistakenly believed that medieval universities were mostly seminaries. In fact they were more law schools. And at least in our tradition lawyers are advocates, trained to take either side of an argument and make as good a case for it as they can. Whether cause or effect, this spirit pervaded early universities. The study of rhetoric, the art of arguing persuasively, was a third of the undergraduate curriculum.

The other big difference between a real essay and the things they make you write in school is that a real essay doesn't take a position and then defend it. That principle, like the idea that we ought to be writing about literature, turns out to be another intellectual hangover of long forgotten origins.

The seeds of our miserable high school experiences were sown in 1892, when the National Education Association "formally recommended that literature and composition be unified in the high school course."

This had two drawbacks: (a) an expert on literature need not himself be a good writer, any more than an art historian has to be a good painter, and (b) the subject of writing now tends to be literature, since that's what the professor is interested in.

Writing was one of the casualties. Colleges had long taught English composition. But how do you do research on composition? The professors who taught math could be required to do original math, the professors who taught history could be required to write scholarly articles about history, but what about the professors who taught rhetoric or composition?

As European scholarship gained momentum it became less and less important; by 1350 someone who wanted to learn about science could find better teachers than Aristotle in his own era. [1] But schools change slower than scholarship. In the 19th century the study of ancient texts was still the backbone of the curriculum.

Around 1100, Europe at last began to catch its breath after centuries of chaos, and once they had the luxury of curiosity they rediscovered what we call "the classics." The effect was rather as if we were visited by beings from another solar system. These earlier civilizations were so much more sophisticated that for the next several centuries the main work of European scholars, in almost every field, was to assimilate what they knew.
With the result that writing is made to seem boring and pointless. Who cares about symbolism in Dickens?
Certainly schools should teach students how to write. But due to a series of historical accidents the teaching of writing has gotten mixed together with the study of literature.

So why is the situation different in trading?
The profitable trades that exist in the world are either (a) the ones you‚Äôre intimately involved in running, or (b) the ones that are inaccessible to you. There is no (c).

I think that, if you had only five minutes with a world-class trader, and you asked her ‚Äúteach me the essentials of trading,‚Äù probably she would spend the five minutes on adverse selection. The essential lesson is that, if you are being offered a trade, that probably means it‚Äôs a bad trade; your job is to understand that thoroughly so you can figure out the exceptions.

content: In the short term, I decided to buy a couple of Guppyfriend bags -- bags you can wash your plastic clothing in. You put the clothes in the bag in the washing machine, the fibers get caught in the bag, like little pieces of lint, and then you can collect them and put them in the garbage so they won't go into the wastewater.
Put in starkest terms, where we end up with this is that I could dress more sustainably by buying and wearing used, shapeless items, and just not looking good.
You read any serious piece about fashion and fit and they will tell you that to look good, you have to get your clothes tailored to fit your body by someone who knows what they are doing.
Why not? I could say I've been busy, a stock answer that is also true, but I think the real reason goes deeper. The truth is that I avoid natural fabrics because I think they won't look good on me.

If you follow this issue at all, you know it is not simple. Producing cotton uses a ton of natural resources and energy; raising sheep for wool is an eco-disaster as well as often cruel to the sheep. I looked up silk and OK, how did I not know that making silk requires dissolving massive numbers of silkworms in boiling water?
The main problem with most athleisure-wear is that it's made of plastic, and we now know that plastic clothes are causing tiny plastic fibers to pollute everything from oceans to breast milk.

The CCP‚Äôs arrival in Kashgar follows that of Mongols, Manchus and a cast of other colonizers. Yet the city of Kashgar will outlast that, as it did the Mongols and the Manchus.

The final section showcases students and educational institutions, including Kashgar Teachers College. When Bubriski visited, Uyghur students could receive an education in their own language; teachers had not yet been forced into the absurdity of teaching them in Mandarin.
Next, Bubriski presents the Old City before the demolitions. These images of intimate Uyghur spaces, a refuge from the forces of sinicization, are of places forever lost.
Homes, businesses and community spaces were wrecked, rebuilt and exploited for tourism, as outlined in a report by the Uyghur Human Rights Project, where I work.

Then in February 2009, officials began carrying out a large-scale demolition as part of a ‚Äúresidents resettlement project‚Äù aimed at moving 220,000 Uyghurs (approximately half of Kashgar‚Äôs population) to other parts of the city.

For these latest colonizers, indelibility is expressed by demolishing the Old City and building a ‚Äúmodern‚Äù Kashgar in the image of the rest of China, cleansed of its Uyghurness and easier to control. That Uyghurs have not been grateful enough for this gift of development has only led to increasing repression, including a network of camps, prisons and surveillance across Xinjiang in recent years.

Back then, Kashgar was still unmistakably a Uyghur city first, and a Chinese city second: its homes, businesses, schools and places of worship were filled with everyday life that carried the knowledge of the past into an irrepressible present and uncertain future.

Pharrell, when I met him, reminded me of a fairy king. Thug reminds me more of the Shakespearean kind, consumed, probably understanding that he's in a tragedy. But the strange thing about the interview wasn't how weird and otherworldly he was.

But in the sense that he seems not to know how you (and by you, I mean me and most of the people reading this article) see the world. He cannot translate himself for you. He does not appear to have any interest in trying. He does not code shift, as they say. He has only a single code. Among artists, he may be the most authentic I've ever met.
Thug is able to channel a kind of genuine nihilism that most people rapping about their rough neighborhoods just can't do.

People‚Äîeven people who live in the same world he does‚Äîfind Young Thug to be truly scary. One of his primary character traits is: disproportionate response. All stakes are high with him‚ÄîI saw Thug and his sister almost cause a riot because a door wasn't opened for them at the Weeknd show.
Bennie, the brother Thug saw die on the sidewalk, was killed over a gambling dispute. ‚ÄúBut Thug gonna do what Thug gonna do.‚Äù He would stay at this table gambling until two the next afternoon.

But it wasn't just the same as his other music. I listened to his new mixtape, Slime Season 3, the music he was playing in the car, a lot (all Thug does is play music loudly, and all he plays is his own music), and‚Ä¶it's better than anything Thug's done until now.

His main security guard carries a semiautomatic assault rifle even when Thug's at the recording studio. Just the week before, a former security guard had been assassinated in his home near downtown Atlanta. No sign of forced entry. Shot to the back of the head.
He is known to have a temper, to have more‚Äîand more dangerous‚Äîbad blood with different factions in Atlanta than any other rapper.

Thug drinks prescription cough syrup all day, takes Xanax, smokes marijuana, eats molly. Sometimes he does all of them at once. He rarely sleeps. A former friend said Thug would stay up for days, take lots of different kinds of drugs, then sleep for 24 to 48 hours.

His little sister Dora, whom he calls his twin, is almost constantly by his side. They call one of his brothers, phonetically, Oonphoonk. Oonphoonk is in prison on a murder conviction‚Äîanother of Thug's brothers was murdered outside his house when Thug was a kid.

He had nothing, his first manager says, when he began rapping. Like, a few shirts, a pair of shoes. He was shy then. He didn't have the gold front teeth yet; his teeth were rotted, discolored. He covered them with his hand when he talked.
He wears little girls' dresses as shirts sometimes, women's pants. When he likes something, he calls it sexy. He calls a Gucci shirt sexy, he calls men sexy, and women he flirts with.

He is 24 years old and six feet three inches tall but has the tiniest little feet, size 8.5, like someone had bound them when he was a child. A 26-inch waist. He eats almost nothing. Says he does not like to eat, and goes for days without food.
What beefs does he have?
Because what does hardball even mean to a guy like Thug, who speaks openly about sex, about the drugs he does, about the beefs he has?

He wears women‚Äôs Uggs but travels with AR-15‚Äôs everywhere he goes. He calls his friends, the same ones carrying the AR-15‚Äôs, ‚Äúbabe‚Äù and ‚Äúlover‚Äù yet is from one of the toughest parts of Atlanta‚Äîthe south side‚Äîwhere he is at once a hero and an outsider and a leader of the psychedelic fashion movement of rap hippies.
I can‚Äôt even imagine this level of confidence haha

He has been known to sit with an interviewer and not answer questions. Not even betray that he knows there is another person in a room with him. GQ once scheduled a photo shoot with him, and he could not be persuaded to get off his kitchen counter to have his picture taken (though clearly, as you can see, he enjoys having his picture taken). He didn't say no; he just never acknowledged that anyone had asked him anything.

content: No breathless whispering of Mark Andreessen across some gilded dinner table. Just a real company making real money by selling useful services around reading. What a thing! A company that loves reading and thinking about reading and meaningfully engaging with reading.
Again, unlike dumping these into my Kindle, there is no fear of ‚Äúcontaminating‚Äù my library view.
When I write on my laptop, the internet is off and I‚Äôm in a fullscreen mode, light text on a dark background.

Overall, I‚Äôm inspired and happy ‚Äî happy to have found a durable solution to a non-trivial problem: How do you engage with deeply researched, lovingly edited texts that exist mainly (if only ‚Äî increasingly only) in digital form?

But for me, the fact that Kindle books and Long Form articles can live side by side in perfect harmony is the true killer ‚Äúapp.‚Äù I‚Äôve long since tried to shoehorn long form into the Kindle through various jankeries, but it‚Äôs never worked reliably, and organization has been terrible ‚Äî a big mess overall. Now? Sublimity.

I‚Äôve installed the Kindle app and Reader app and that‚Äôs it. That‚Äôs all I touch on this guy. Yes, you could buy an iPad Mini or an old iPhone and do sort of the same thing ‚Äî but ‚Ä¶ that glossiness ‚Ä¶ that Ferrari engine screaming to peel out-ness ‚Ä¶ it‚Äôs there, right under your fingertips in a way that the BOOX simply doesn‚Äôt have.

Once you hold a Palma, you realize that for most situations it‚Äôs an ideal reading container. On the train? In line? In the waiting room at the doctor‚Äôs office? I‚Äôve carried my Palma with me every day for the past three or so months with the goal of reaching for it rather than my iPhone.

And through the use of a Readwise Obsidian plugin, I have a locally-stored Obsidian Vault with a full archive of all of my Kindle highlights and notes, with deep-linking into the Kindle app, and highlights from any 
long form articles I‚Äôve read.

I learned about BOOX because a company I‚Äôve long followed and admired ‚Äî Readwise ‚Äî asked me to be an advisor. I did a call with Readwise‚Äôs CEO and we talked about digital 
reading.
Largely, this is a container issue, in that our containers are just so deliciously optimized for not reading.

Don‚Äôt even have that dopamine bastard within earshot. One little buzz of an incoming something-something will break the spell of the book, send your mind racing with casino chemicals. You think I‚Äôm exaggerating! I haven‚Äôt slept with a phone in my bedroom in over a decade ‚Äî I get a lot of good reading done at night in bed.
The easiest way to do this kind of reading? Pick up a physical book published by a publishing house that cares without compromise.
Yes! Im doing less and less of this of late.

love reading. (Perhaps you do, too!) Now, there are many forms of ‚Äúreading,‚Äù and you can spend your whole day doing ‚Äúreading‚Äù and not actually do the kind of reading we love. The kind we love is focused, challenging, sustained, with a pen in hand, making note of new turns of phrase and peculiar, precise words, and feeling our brains get ever-so-slightly reconfigured by the text.

content: Mainly because: It‚Äôs been boring / depressing. Not much has happened. Patents and monopolies chopped the feet off digital books. Well

A long time ago, in a universe far, far away, I used to write about / really care about digital reading. A whole chapter of my life / career pivoted around digital reading and books, what could be, and I travelled the world (?!) talking about this stuff.

There‚Äôs aren‚Äôt many capitalistic levers of this size accessible to mere consumers. Books ‚Äî novels especially ‚Äî operate on such a freakishly micro scale (literally thousands vs tens-of-thousand or hundreds-of-thousands or millions like so much else in media) that banging a preorder drum until you‚Äôre blue in the face is a pretty critical (if humbling) author activity.

Google and Facebook are a meta-layer on top of the web, and most of the ad money on the web goes to them as result, but they don‚Äôt replace the web, and when newspapers claim that if they appear in a Google search then Google should pay them, it‚Äôs actually very hard to find anyone, even at a newspaper company, willing to claim this makes any sense. Newspapers, after all, don‚Äôt pay a movie studio a share of their revenue when they review a film.
Google reads most of the web every couple of days, and indexes it, and it makes money from doing this. It makes money from your content, but it does that by telling people about you.
Analysis of Canada‚Äôs tax on links to news on Facebook: less engagement for news, no impact on Facebook.

Instead of focusing on labels, it's more important to consider the functional characteristics and how they help achieve goals. The author also suggests embracing the spectrum of serverless technologies instead of arguing about specific boundaries. While the term may be losing meaning, the underlying concepts are still valuable.

title: A failed attempt at monetizing technical writing
author: Luc van Donkersgoed's Notes
summary: Luc Vandonkersgoed embarked on a failed attempt to monetize his technical writing through a website called Bite-Sized Serverless. The site offered a combination of free and paid articles about AWS Serverless, with the hope of attracting readers with the free content and upselling them on the paid articles. However, the monetization model and the restrictive content format proved to be failures. The lack of a trial or free preview for paid articles and the limited scope of the content led to low revenue generation. Additionally, Vandonkersgoed's decision to build his own platform instead of using an existing product, like WordPress, consumed valuable time that could have been spent on writing content. Ultimately, he has decided to return to his roots and run his personal website on WordPress.com, focusing on writing different types of content without plans for monetization.

title: When AWS invariants aren't [invariant]
author: Aidan Steele's blog (usually about AWS)
summary: The document discusses how to identify instances where AWS invariants are not being upheld by searching CloudTrail for specific events. It highlights the importance of understanding certain conditions, such as how employees access AWS solely through Okta/AssumeRoleWithSAML and how some roles were previously allowed to assume themselves. The document also mentions changes made by AWS regarding role trust policy evaluation behavior and the need for explicit trust grants for role assumption. This information is crucial for maintaining security and compliance within AWS environments.

The process involved setting up redirects, tracking clicks, and displaying community spotlights based on user engagement data, all managed through automation. Future plans include expanding the system's capabilities and addressing storage limitations by archiving older data.

title: I love serverless, but it got something dramatically wrong
author: Jeremy Daly
summary: Serverless technology has closely coupled the underlying cloud infrastructure with app and business logic, creating a bifurcation of business logic and tying the performance of applications to architectural decisions made in the app code. This requires developers to understand the impact of choosing different statically configured primitives, which can be challenging when also trying to be competent in multiple programming languages and cloud services. Platform engineering has emerged to allow developers to be more productive while maintaining security, performance, and cost. However, many developers may not have the time or desire to invest in learning new services and keeping up with the latest features. While serverless has its advantages, upskilling organizations to effectively deploy serverless applications can take years of experimentation and learning. The goal is to enable developers to write code and solve user problems while harnessing the power of the public cloud, which requires a different approach.

title: Hating Apple goes mainstream
author: David Heinemeier Hansson (dhh@hey.com)
summary: This isn't just about one awful ad. I mean, yes, the ad truly is awful. It symbolizes everything everyone has ever hated about digitization. It celebrates a lossy, creative compression for the most flimsy reason: An iPad shedding an irrelevant millimeter or two. It's destruction of beloved musical instruments is the perfect metaphor for how utterly tone-deaf technologists are capable of being. But the real story is just how little saved up goodwill Apple had in the bank to compensate for the outrage.That's because Apple has lost its presumption of good faith over the last five years with an ever-larger group of people, and now we've reached a tipping point. A year ago, I'm sure this awful ad would have gotten push back, but I'm also sure we'd heard more "it's not that big of a deal" and "what Apple really meant to say was..." from the stalwart Apple apologists the company has been able to count on for decades. But it's awfully quiet on the fan-boy front.This should all be eerily familiar to anyone who saw Micro...

You start in your 20s and keep being a ‚Äúserial entrepreneur‚Äù until it clicks. The authors, however, found no evidence of this at all. In fact what happens is that young people attempt new businesses, go into debt, run out of luck, enter a period of demoralization, and then face the grim realities of life: you are far better off getting a job, buckling down, learning a trade, and then once you have experience and social capital, try your hand at starting something new.

Communication with the external service supplier is important, especially if the service is being used as part of a production application.

Nx supports running commands across multiple machines. You can either set it up by hand or use Nx Cloud. Read the comparison of the two approaches.When using the distributed task execution, Nx is able to run any task graph on many agents instead of locally.For
So I think this is what we want to use.

When you run nx affected -t test, Nx looks at the files you changed in your PR, it will look at the nature of change (what exactly did you update in those files), and it uses this to figure the list of projects in the workspace that can be affected by this change. It then runs the run-many command with that list.
Ok so what does it have now?

Nx analyzes your file system to detect projects. Projects are identified by the presence of a package.json file or project.json file. Projects identification can also be customized through plugins. You can manually define dependencies between the project nodes, but you don‚Äôt have to do it very often. Nx analyzes files‚Äô source code, your installed dependencies, TypeScript files, and others figuring out these dependencies for you

I mean this is Wild.

A developer checks out someone else's PR branch to help troubleshoot a problem. They run the tests and all the successful tests finish instantly. They can focus their debugging time on the few tests that are still failing
This is because affected compares the current commit with the main branch every time.
So he would need to have many projects and we don't
The affected command compares the PR against the main branch and only runs tasks for projects that could have been affected by the code changes

title: IntegrationTest
author: Martin Fowler
summary: Integration tests are used to determine if independently developed units of software work correctly when they are connected to each other. However, there is confusion around the term "integration test" and its scope. In the past, integration testing involved combining modules into the entire system or significant sub-systems to test their interactions. Nowadays, a narrower approach to integration testing is becoming more popular, where only the portion of code interacting with a separate service is tested using test doubles. This approach offers faster testing and easier integration with external services. However, there are still developers who only understand integration tests as broad tests that require live versions of all services. It is important to clarify the terminology and consider the benefits of narrow integration testing.

If not things like money, awards, honors, prizes, and medals‚Äîwhat should we strive for? ‚ÄúWhen we were writing Good Will Hunting,‚Äù Matt Damon said, ‚ÄúBen [Affleck] and I always talked about just wanting to love it. We would say, ‚ÄòIf it‚Äôs just a tape on our mantel that no one ever watches, we want to love it.‚Äô We kind of stumbled into a very wise strategy, which is to try to get most of the rewards from the work itself.‚Äù

As everyone emptied out of Radio City Music Hall, they talked about what after-party they were attending and what they were going to eat and what they were working on next. Kail stood on stage alone and thought, ‚ÄúWell if this is a pinnacle, and it‚Äôs over in an instant, and people are already talking about what‚Äôs next, it can‚Äôt be about this. It has to be about something more than this.‚Äù

The Olympics‚ÄîI was lucky to be in 3 Olympics‚Äîare an amazing pinnacle of what sport is, and it‚Äôs fun to be on that stage, but the other 99.9% of the time, you‚Äôre not on that stage. And so it has to be about something more than that‚Äîif all you really cared about was that .01% of what your career entailed, you‚Äôd be missing out on your entire life. If you define yourself or your career by that .01%, that‚Äôs really unfortunate.‚Äù

To let 0.0000641% of an experience determine one‚Äôs happiness or satisfaction is a heartbreaking waste of one‚Äôs life. ‚ÄúMy heart broke,‚Äù Damon said. ‚ÄúI imagined another one of me [not getting that award until I was] an old man, and going like, ‚ÄòOh my god, Where did my life go? What have I done?‚Äô And then it‚Äôs over.‚Äù

As he looked at it, he was suddenly overwhelmed by a heartbreaking thought: ‚ÄúI remember very clearly looking at that award and thinking, ‚ÄòImagine chasing that, not getting it, and then getting it finally in your 80s or your 90s with all of life behind you and realizing what an unbelievable waste of your life.‚Äô‚Äù Damon stood on the Oscars stage for eighty-one seconds.

Public markets are among the only institutions big enough to write the size of checks they demand. In other words, private equity and venture capital aren‚Äôt permanently devouring young companies; they‚Äôre just delaying the emergence of these companies as publicly traded stocks.

The existence of giant pools of capital outside the public markets is likely playing some role, as it allows entrepreneurs to stay private longer. That slows the conveyor belt of new companies to public markets.

Of course, this begs the question of why we‚Äôre designing our cities around our fire trucks rather than the other way around. Smaller fire trucks perform well in European and Asian cities with tall buildings and lower fire death rates. They‚Äôre also more maneuverable, important for urban situations where trucks may be asked to squeeze into and through tight spaces.

If our sole goal is to save as many lives as possible, we should be willing to accept some increase in fire deaths in exchange for a larger decrease in car crash deaths. Given we have approximately 16 times as many car crash deaths as structure fire deaths, it would require an 80% increase in fire deaths to equal a 5% decrease in car crash deaths.

Doing so would allow multifamily buildings to be built more affordably and efficiently, unlocking apartment layouts that can more easily access light and air. Fire departments, naturally, are in opposition.

But in American cities‚Äîespecially my own NYC‚Äîit‚Äôs all too common to see fire trucks, ambulances, and other emergency vehicles stuck in bumper-to-bumper jams behind private cars. Congestion pricing, which firefighters vocally oppose, would reduce the traffic that the FDNY has claimed is causing slower response times.

Narrower lanes‚Äîparticularly on urban streets‚Äîhave been repeatedly shown to lead to reduced speeds and safer roads. By forging Poisson en masse, we obliterate the trail of provenance for the artwork. Though physically undamaged, we destroy any future confidence in the veracity of the work. By burying a needle in a needlestack, we render the original as much a forgery as any of our replications.

Ubiquity is the darkness in which novelty and the avant-garde die their truest deaths. More than slashed canvas or burned pages, democratization of access or ownership destroys any work premised on exclusivity.

Imagine that all organized criminal groups exist on a spectrum between devotion to commerce and honor. Gangs on the far end of one side of the spectrum operate exactly like a business that just so happens to service and elicit market; they don‚Äôt engage in violence except as a measure of last resort to protect profits. Gangs on the extreme opposite side of the spectrum barely or don‚Äôt care about money at all; they are focused on respect, both for the gang as a whole and the individuals within them.

content: By selecting the train engineer at random, release process knowledge and load is gradually spread throughout the organization

One of the philosophies at Nextdoor is to align incentives at the right levels to boost productivity as much as possible. Toward this goal, we pick a random individual who has a change on the train to be the ‚Äútrain engineer‚Äù. The train engineer is responsible for frontline triage of issues.

When a change lands on master, if there is already an existing train, it is queued for the next train. To use a train-based metaphor, the changes are ‚Äúwaiting on the platform‚Äù until a new train arrives. Note that before a change can be landed on master, a large suite of automated tests must pass and it must be accepted by a human reviewer

However at the scale of the Nextdoor monolith, this isn‚Äôt usually possible. Given the test, build and deploy overhead of our monolith (about 25 minutes total), if we released a single change at a time, changes would get backed up and it could take hours between engineers landing their changes on master and them going out to production.
Engineers land directly to master and we avoid long-lived branches.

title: How Nextdoor made a 10x improvement in release times with Docker and Amazon ECS
author: Niall O'Higgins
summary: At the beginning of 2016, Nextdoor production releases took about an hour. That is to say, once all the code in the new release was tested‚Ä¶

content: This is also complicated by the fact that tickets often also have a "definition of done", common when using agile frameworks such as SCRUM. Even when talking about a specific ticket though, "deploying to production" doesn't necessarily mean the ticket is done. A single ticket may require several PRs and each one will be deployed to production separately.

Rather than working on functionality in isolation then delivering the entire piece at the end, you must become comfortable continuously delivering small parts of the overall solution and potentially exposing code that is often a work-in-progress or an experiment that may have to be rethought later on. It takes quite a while to get used to this, but eventually it becomes second nature and all is forgiven once you start noticing the benefits of this way of working.

In order for Continuous Delivery to work, developers must become accustomed to committing changes to the main branch "at least once a day" as a general guideline (this is actually a requirement of Continuous Integration which is a prerequisite for Continuous Delivery).

Testing is just as important as ever but now, you write your tests while continuously going to production instead of trying to get everything perfect up front before going to production. It's a very different approach. It requires a mindset shift and in some cases unlearning habits you may have held close for years!

If your change is a smaller part of a bigger feature that won't be released to end users for a while yet, you can push it to production during development behind a feature flag with the confidence end users won't be affected.

A pillar of modern application development, continuous delivery expands upon continuous integration by deploying all code changes to a testing environment and/or a production environment after the build stage. When properly implemented, developers will always have a deployment-ready build artifact that has passed through a standardized test process
This build and test stack not only runs on every commit, but also runs multiple times during the life cycle of any code change. On Android alone, we do between 50,000 and 60,000 builds a day.
Shipping on mobile platforms presents more of a challenge, as many of the current development and deployment tools available for mobile make rapid iteration difficult.
I mean we just need a front and per our system and we are close

It eliminates the need for hotfixes. In the three-push-a-day system, if a critical change had to get out and it wasn‚Äôt during one of the scheduled push times, someone had to call for a hotfix. These out-of-band pushes were disruptive because they usually needed some human action and could bump into the next scheduled push
Each release is rolled out to 100 percent of production in a tiered fashion over a few hours, so we can stop the push if we find any problems
After almost exactly a year of planning and development, over the course of three days in April 2017 we enabled 100 percent of our production web servers to run code deployed directly from master.

This system scaled well, starting with a handful of engineers in 2007 to thousands today. The good news is that as we added more engineers, we got more done ‚Äî the rate of code delivery scaled with the size of the team. But it took a certain amount of human effort in the form of release engineers, in addition to the tools and automated systems in place, to drive the daily and weekly pushes out the door. We understood that batching up larger and larger chunks of code for delivery would not continue to scale as the team kept growing.
All these methodologies have one common goal: to enable developers to get their code out quickly and correctly to the people who use it, in safe, small, incremental steps.

content: A good canary result in AWS / us-east-1 does not tell you that version N+1 is good to go everywhere, it tells you that N+1 was fine in AWS / us-east-1 at that point in time, with the runtime configuration that was live at that time (including the specific set of enabled feature flags).
I would love to see us add this.

even a single canary instance can cause significant damage if you leave it unattended for the full incubation period (200 RPS of errors for 1h is a lot of errors). Consider having automation in place to kill really bad canaries early, no need to throw errors for more than a couple minutes

beware the forgotten feature flag: it is possible to sneak features past a canary with a disabled feature flag. Obviously not great when you turn it on and it blows up in prod (on the upside, only the feature needs to be reverted, not the whole rollout). As a workaround, consider having feature flags enabled by default and require an explicit configuration change to disable.
As a corollary, you should consider fighting the urge to add more and more metrics after each incident (e.g. when someone asks ‚Äúwhy wasn‚Äôt this caught by the canary?‚Äù).
For instance, you may have an error that breaks 0.1% of your customers very badly: very hard to catch in a canary, but potentially thousands of angry phone calls as a result
We could use this at sone point.
consider running an A/A canary where the canary cluster runs the same version as the prod cluster. If

A workaround for this is to introduce a dedicated baseline cluster at version N that is created at the same time as the canary cluster. The canary is then compared against that new baseline cluster, not against the prod cluster. But again, beware small services.
Many of our metrics end up here.

if a deviation in any metric can cause the canary to fail, then canaries are likely to fail left and right and devs will get desensitized to bad canary results (sometimes causing incidents because of the decision to push despite poor canary results

What metrics should be looked at and how should they be compared? On one end of the spectrum, you would only look at the HTTP error rate over the incubation period [1] (num_http_4XX + num_http_5XX)/num_requests (this would prevent catastrophic rollouts e.g. a service that returns 500 all the time but might miss subtler issues related to business logic). On the other hand of the spectrum, you would look at all the metrics exposed by the service (CPU, latency, memory usage, GC pauses, business logic errors, downstream dependencies, cache hits and misses, timeouts, connection errors‚Ä¶). The problem with this approach is that you may now be dealing with noisy signals

Running canaries this way is now a major incident risk ‚Äì ideally your load balancer/service discovery mechanism would let you control a percentage of traffic to send to the canary cluster, not just a portion of traffic based on the number of prod instances
I think we do this on accident for sessions. '

To work around this, it is possible to implement sticky canaries, assigning not just a percentage of traffic but a percentage of users to a canary. The potential ethical conundrum here is that you may have just completely broken the user experience of your poor group of guinea pig users that have been assigned to a canary ‚Äútest cell‚Äù for however long your incubation period is. So be mindful of this, and ideally rotate users in and out of the canary cell quickly enough so that they don‚Äôt experience obnoxious disruptions

They had been deploying less than 10 times per year; they set a goal of 50 times per year (thinking they wouldn't be able to keep the twice per week schedule going). They surprised themselves and easily exceeded 100 deployments per year, and their deployment success rate was over 90%

title: Automated Canary Analysis at Netflix with Kayenta
author: Netflix Technology Blog
summary: Netflix has open sourced Kayenta, a platform for Automated Canary Analysis (ACA), in partnership with Google. ACA is a technique used to reduce the risk when deploying new software versions by comparing key metrics between the new version (canary) and the stable version. Kayenta is integrated with Netflix's continuous delivery platform, Spinnaker, and is responsible for assessing the risk of a canary release. It retrieves metrics from the baseline and canary clusters and uses a series of steps, including data validation, cleaning, metric comparison, and score computation, to determine if the canary passed or failed. Kayenta is designed to be flexible and pluggable, and it is currently being used for approximately 30% of Netflix's production canary judgments.

In November, Google‚Äôs DeepMind division claimed that their AI tool GNoME found 2.2 million new crystals, of which 384,870 are stable materials that could be used in future tech, an achievement that they claimed pushed the science forward substantially. Outside researchers who attempted to verify those claims have, in a new perspective paper published in Chemical Materials, expressed serious misgivings about that claim. A team selected a random sample of the 384,870 proposed structure and found that not a single one met a three-part test of being credible, useful or novel. They also call out 18,000 proposed compounds that contain elements that are only available in minute quantities, or are far too radioactive to actually have any utility whatsoever in materials science. DeepMind stands by its paper.

title: This US startup makes a crucial chip material and is taking on a Japanese giant

content: woah that is fascinating...

On every computer chip, separating and insulating the copper wires is a material called a dielectric. The dielectric film placed between the chip and the structure underneath is produced as an incredibly thin sheet, and for the past three decades a single Japanese company has had over 90 percent market share in dielectric film. That company is Ajinomoto, which connoisseurs may better know as the company that is the leading global supplier of MSG seasoning powder. In the ‚Äò90s, Ajinomoto found that one of the byproducts of MSG production was a dielectric insulator, and thus a monopoly was born. They have nothing whatsoever to do with making computer chips beyond this one thing. Given recent investments in chips, some new companies intend to challenge Ajinomoto‚Äôs domination in the market.

A new study published in Biological Conservation sought to figure out a safe, convenient way to deter grizzly bears from encountering humans at sites where, for instance, some grain has spilled from storage bins. Livestock guardian dogs have traditionally had a very specific role ‚Äî they guard livestock, says it all there in the name ‚Äî but for the study were set to be stationed on farms in Montana regularly visited by the grizzlies. The GPS data collected from the study found that there was an 88 percent reduction in the number of bears that came within 300 meters of farms with dogs, and those that did make an attempt to go to those farms spent 94 percent less time at the farms with dogs than the control group.

title: What is Continuous Delivery?
author: continuousdelivery.com
summary: Continuous Delivery is the practice of safely and quickly getting changes, such as new features and bug fixes, into production or the hands of users. The goal is to make deployments predictable and routine by ensuring that code is always in a deployable state. This eliminates the need for integration, testing, and code freezes. Continuous Delivery offers several benefits, including low-risk releases, faster time to market, higher quality, lower costs, and better products. It also leads to happier teams by reducing the pain associated with software delivery and allowing for more frequent engagement with users. Continuous Delivery is not a magic solution, but rather a continuous improvement process that aims for higher performance.

title: CanaryRelease
author: Continuous Delivery
summary: Canary release is a technique used to reduce the risk of introducing a new software version in production by gradually rolling it out to a small subset of users before making it available to everyone. This method allows for capacity testing in a production environment with a safe rollback strategy if issues arise. Companies employ various strategies, such as targeting specific user groups or regions, to implement canary releases effectively. While similar to A/B testing, canary releases focus on detecting problems and regressions, making them distinct approaches for software deployment.

This led the authors to estimate that bacteria in subsurface sediments may make up as much as two-thirds of total bacterial biomass.

The subsurface ecosystems turned out to have a great diversity of microbes, including not only the sulfate-reducing bacteria found at the vents but a new type that got its energy from carbon reactions. It is important to not only discover who you are but also maximize and embody your truest self. The world is like a mirror, reflecting back distorted versions of ourselves. Through the consumption and synthesis of these reflections, we can connect to our inner source code and understand our place and role in the world. Despite the imperfections of life, the pursuit of self-discovery and self-expression is a profound purpose.

Why are we so fucking cheap?

title: More (self-)publishing thoughts.
author: Irrational Exuberance
summary: The author shares insights on self-publishing based on their experience with three books and various publishing methods. They discuss the importance of learning from both traditional publishing and self-publishing, highlighting the benefits and drawbacks of each approach. Factors like pricing control, print quality, creative control, and international rights management are compared between working with a publisher and self-publishing. The author emphasizes that the decision to self-publish is context-dependent, with no universally right choice and encourages a balanced approach for maximizing learning and success in publishing.

title: Ex-technology companies.
author: Irrational Exuberance
summary: Some companies are losing their "technology company" status due to various reasons, such as being unable to achieve zero marginal costs or having R&D efforts that don't impact the business. The shift impacts how employees experience working at these companies and how investors value them. It's crucial for companies to assess if their R&D can significantly improve their financial profile to determine their position in this changing landscape.

title: Mid Career Stuckness
author: because writing is clarifying
summary:
It may sound harsh, but let me offer a hypothesis ‚Äî most of us get disillusioned and potentially stuck in mid-careers, and the most common cause is not learning about power and influence early enough. It is not a lack of technical knowledge and related competencies that makes one get stuck in their mid-career ‚Äî it is the lack of an understanding of their power, the power of others, and then not developing their sources of power and using those to influence others to get things done ‚Äî is what gets you stuck often. This stuckness starts with an improper understanding of ‚Äúpower‚Äù and ‚Äúinfluence‚Äù and subsequently not recognizing and appreciating your power and that of others. Based on an ad hoc sample, I can tell that many people at work secretly hope that power doesn‚Äôt exist and stay away from it, which is sad and career-limiting.
Why is this usually a mid-career phenomenon? In the early-career phase, your technical competencies get you the job and, perhaps, a few promotions. By technical, I don‚Äôt mean competencies ...

title: Seabound: Charting a Course to Decarbonize Shipping
author: Collaborative Fund
summary: Seabound, a company focused on decarbonizing shipping, was invested in by the Shared Future Fund in 2022 and has been making significant progress since then. Their innovative approach involves capturing CO2 onboard ships to create clean fuel, addressing the challenges of sourcing affordable CO2 for fuel production. Seabound's unique carbon capture technology converts CO2 into limestone onboard, simplifying the process by completing the separation and liquefaction onshore. The company aims to transform the shipping industry by providing sustainable solutions and hopes to see carbon-negative ships on the water within the next decade. Their plans include using recent funding to accelerate product development and commercialization to meet the increasing demands for green shipping solutions.

title: Ambient Co-presence
author: Maggie Appleton
summary: Creating a subtle sense of shared synchronous space on the web is challenging. The current web experience lacks the qualities of shared physical space and the ability to be aware of others in real-time. However, advancements in internet speeds and bandwidth have allowed for real-time experiences like collaborative editing and live streaming. The concept of ambient co-presence, where people share a space without direct interaction, is still relatively unexplored in the digital realm. Multiplayer cursors and spatial audio are potential solutions, but further exploration is needed to achieve a softer, ambient sense of shared presence.

title: Speculative Calendar Events
author: Maggie Appleton
summary: The author discusses the challenges of scheduling speculative events and proposes the idea of a new type of calendar event: the speculative event. These events may or may not happen and therefore show up tentatively with a dashed border and light opacity. The author suggests adding an "unconfirmed" checkbox to the editing window of calendar events and turning off their notifications. The author also mentions that some calendar startups are trying to solve this problem, but the proposed solutions feel a bit impersonal and automated.

title: Gathering Structures
author: Maggie Appleton
summary: The document provides insights on gathering structures for organizing events and communities. It discusses the challenges faced by organizers, such as dealing with disruptive participants and managing logistics. Various strategies like hosting demos under time constraints, rotating hosts for smaller groups, and using social-shaped structures for discussions are highlighted. The document also touches on the concept of gatekeeping to ensure events have a high-quality, engaged audience. Additionally, it emphasizes starting small and simple to build successful communities and events.

title: Spinning Worlds, Seasickness, and Dealing with Vestibular Neuritis
author: Maggie Appleton
summary: The document details a personal experience with vestibular neuritis, describing symptoms of severe dizziness, disorientation, and anxiety. The author shares a journey of medical uncertainty, from initial misdiagnoses to finally being diagnosed with vestibular neuritis. The narrative discusses the challenges of navigating symptoms like brain fog, light sensitivity, and the relief of finding support and information from others with similar experiences. The account emphasizes the importance of seeking medical help, managing expectations for recovery, and finding reassurance through shared experiences in dealing with vestibular issues.

title: Logseq from an Org-mode Point of View
author: public voit
summary: Logseq is a knowledge management and note-taking tool that offers an alternative to Org-mode in Emacs. It uses Markdown as the default lightweight markup language, but also supports Org-mode syntax. Logseq is block-oriented, allowing for the addition of metadata to each block and easy linking between blocks and pages. The tool offers features like collapsible blocks, queries, templates, and plugins for added functionality. However, Logseq does have some limitations compared to Org-mode, such as the lack of Elisp customization, appointments, and certain editing functions. Overall, Logseq provides a user-friendly interface and useful features for organizing and navigating information.

Here‚Äôs how it worked: When I had a decision to make, I‚Äôd first convert it into a set of actions to choose between. I would then decide which one to choose with the help of a random number generator on my phone. The RNG would produce a number between one and 100. If that number was six or higher, I‚Äôd go with the option that had historically led to the most preferable results. An actual reinforcement learning algorithm helps score how preferable a given option is based on the computer agent‚Äôs past observations. I would crudely approximate this by reflecting on the outcomes of similar decisions I‚Äôd made in the past.

title: Farewell EC2-Classic, it‚Äôs been swell
author: werner@allthingsdistributed.com (Dr. Werner Vogels)
summary: On August 15, 2023, Amazon Web Services (AWS) shut down the last instance of EC2-Classic, a service that started cloud computing. EC2-Classic was launched in 2006, and it provided a simple process of acquiring compute, though the stack running behind the scenes was incredibly complex. AWS continued to support Classic for the next decade, even as EC2 evolved. The EC2 team kept Classic running until every instance was shut down or migrated.

title: Standing on the shoulders of giants: Colm on constant work
author: werner@allthingsdistributed.com (Dr. Werner Vogels)
summary: Colm MacC√°rthaigh discusses the concept of anti-fragility in building robust systems, using coffee urns as an analogy for constant work patterns. He explains how systems must maintain reliability and efficiency, especially during peak stress periods, similar to how coffee urns function. The document further explores the application of constant work patterns in Amazon Route 53 health checks and how this approach ensures system reliability and self-healing capabilities, emphasizing the importance of simplicity, redundancy, and cost-effectiveness in system design. The discussion also touches on the use of constant work patterns in configuring foundational components like Network Load Balancers, highlighting the benefits of anti-fragility and automatic error correction within such systems.

title: Tech predictions for 2024 and beyond
author: werner@allthingsdistributed.com (Dr. Werner Vogels)
summary: The document "Tech predictions for 2024 and beyond" discusses several key trends in the tech industry. It highlights the importance of Generative AI becoming culturally aware, which will lead to more inclusive and diverse models. Additionally, it delves into the rise of FemTech, focusing on how investment in women's healthcare is surging and how technology is revolutionizing the sector. The document also explores how AI assistants are redefining developer productivity, evolving from basic code generators to comprehensive collaborators. Lastly, it touches on the need for education to adapt to the rapid pace of technological innovation, emphasizing the emergence of industry-led skills-based training programs.

title: What I've been reading since re:Invent
author: werner@allthingsdistributed.com (Dr. Werner Vogels)
summary: After attending re:Invent, Amazon's annual technology conference, Werner Vogels, the company's CTO, has been reading a range of books. He recommends Right/Wrong: How Technology Transforms Our Ethics by Juan Enriquez for those interested in understanding how ethics and morals can change under the influence of technology. Vogels also recommends The Age of American Unreason in a Culture of Lies by Susan Jacoby and Anti-Intellectualism in American Life by Douglas Hofstadter, both of which provide insight into how politics and public language have devolved in recent decades. Additionally, Vogels has been reading various biographies, including Down and Out in Paradise: The Life of Anthony Bourdain by Charles Leerhsen and Adrenaline: My Untold Stories by Zlatan Ibrahimovic. Finally, he recommends a paper from the Netflix Technology Blog titled "Rebuilding Netflix Video Processing Pipeline with Microservices".

title: District heating: Using data centers to heat communities
author: werner@allthingsdistributed.com (Dr. Werner Vogels)
summary: The document highlights the Tallaght District Heating Scheme in Ireland, a collaboration between various entities to provide heat and hot water to a range of buildings using a district heating system. The program aims to reduce emissions and relies on renewable and underutilized energy sources, such as heat from data centers. Monitoring plays a vital role in ensuring the system's efficiency, and the collaboration has significantly reduced carbon emissions in the area. Plans are in place to expand the program to include residential buildings and other critical infrastructure in the community, demonstrating the potential for sustainable community energy systems.

title: retreating from information flows is just a different way of having your attention hacked by others
author: campaign-archive.com
summary: The document discusses the concept of "Waldenponding," which involves retreating from information flows as a way to reclaim attention from technology and social media platforms. While some people have embraced extreme versions of Waldenponding, such as living off the grid, the author argues that it is not a sustainable or beneficial philosophy. Instead, the document suggests that withdrawing from information flows can also leave individuals vulnerable to having their attention controlled by different fears, such as FOBO (Fear Of Being Ordinary), which is explored as an alternative viewpoint to FOMO (Fear Of Missing Out). The text challenges the idea of Waldenponding as a valid approach to managing attention in the digital age.

title: Best Font for Online Reading: No Single Answer

Garamond was found to have the highest average reading speed, but individual preferences varied greatly. Age also played a role, with older users experiencing a decline in reading speed. The study highlighted the need for personalized font optimization to maximize reading speed for individual users.

title: The Usefulness of Useless Knowledge
author: Abraham Flexner
summary: In "The Usefulness of Useless Knowledge," Abraham Flexner argues that pursuing intellectual and spiritual activities may not have immediate practical applications, but they can lead to unexpected utility and satisfaction of intellectual curiosity. He provides examples from science and mathematics, such as the discovery of electromagnetic waves by Heinrich Hertz and the development of group theory. Flexner also highlights how seemingly aimless work, such as Ehrlich's microscopic observations, can eventually lead to practical applications, such as in medicine. He emphasizes the importance of cultivating curiosity and not solely focusing on immediate practical uses.

title: Eric-Jorgenson_The-Almanack-of-Naval-Ravikant.indd
author: navalmanack.s3.amazonaws.com
summary: This document is a compilation of Naval Ravikant's thoughts and teachings on wealth and happiness. It includes tips on building wealth, such as understanding how wealth is created, finding a position of leverage, and building judgment. The document also discusses happiness, including the idea that happiness is learned, requires presence and peace, and can be found in acceptance. Additionally, the document touches on philosophy and the importance of finding meaning and purpose in life.
notes:
