title: Development of a remotely controllable 4 m long aerial-hose-type firefighting robot
author: Wai-keung Fung
summary: The document discusses the development of a remotely controllable 4m long aerial-hose-type firefighting robot. The robot, known as the Dragon Firefighter (DFF), is designed to extinguish fires safely and efficiently using remote control. It features a flexible body and multiple nozzle units that can manipulate the entire water hose. The document also describes the controller and flow channel design of the DFF, as well as the development of the nozzle units to expand their injection range and improve waterproofing. The robot has been successfully tested in small-scale firefighting demonstrations and is intended to be used in situations where the connected water hose may interfere with the environment.

title: The Simplest Walking Robot
author: College of Engineering, Carnegie Mellon University
summary: The content includes a video titled "The Simplest Walking Robot" and a list of other related videos about robotics and mechanical engineering.

title: LLM in a flash: Efficient Large Language Model Inference with Limited Memory
author: arxiv.org
summary: This paper discusses the challenge of efficiently running large language models (LLMs) with limited DRAM capacity by storing model parameters on flash memory and bringing them on demand to DRAM. The authors propose an inference cost model that optimizes data transfer and reading data in larger chunks. They introduce two techniques, "windowing" and "row-column bundling," to reduce data transfer and increase flash memory throughput. These methods allow LLMs to run models up to twice the size of available DRAM and achieve significant increases in inference speed. The paper also addresses the characteristics of flash memory and the challenges of LLM inference on resource-constrained devices.

title: In Defense of Performance: A Manifesto
author: Brad Stulberg
summary: When the authors began writing about performance, they provided novel language and tools for understanding it. However, as the idea of performance became more popular, it was flattened and appropriated for all kinds of nonsense, such as monetizable clickbait and fuel for marketing. They aim to help people understand what it means to perform at their best in day-to-day life, and provide a list of core principles and specific, evidence-based habits for the body and mind, including consistency over intensity, rugged flexibility over rigidity, and deep reading. The authors also encourage working in intervals and doing real things in the real world, and warn against falling for trendy fads and diets.

title: Ali Abdaal: Is Hard Work Overrated?
author: Tiago Forte
summary: In an interview, Ali Abdaal discusses his upcoming book, "Feelgood Productivity," which argues that productivity doesn't have to be painful and that feeling good can actually make you more productive. Abdaal explains that the idea for the book came from research on positive emotions and the power of feeling good. He also discusses the origins of the myth that work has to be painful and why it persists.

title: Annual Reflection 7 POWERFUL QUESTIONS TO REFLEC T ON 2023 AND M AKE YOURSELF UNSTOPPABLE IN 2024.
author: fsmisc.s3.ca-central-1.amazonaws.com
summary: Annual Reflection provides 7 powerful questions for individuals to reflect on their past year and make themselves unstoppable in the coming year. These questions cover various aspects of personal development, such as analyzing what's working and what isn't, eliminating unnecessary priorities, taking proactive steps instead of waiting passively, avoiding weaknesses, removing toxic people from one's life, emulating successful actions, and playing on easy mode rather than hard mode. By considering these questions and taking appropriate actions, individuals can set themselves up for success in the future.

title: The Making of Arrested Development was a Sh*t Show (Pt 1: Critically Ill-Fated)
author: It Was A Sh*t Show
summary: "The Making of Arrested Development was a Sh*t Show (Pt 1: Critically Ill-Fated)" tells the story of the critically acclaimed sitcom and the challenges it faced during its production. The show was inspired by the rise of reality TV and aimed to revolutionize the sitcom genre. The pilot script was bought by 20th Century Fox, and the show gained a reputation for its unique visual style and unconventional storytelling. Despite positive reviews and Emmy wins, Arrested Development struggled to find a wide audience, and Fox attempted to make the series more accessible in its second season. However, the show ultimately faced cancellation due to low ratings and network priorities.

title: You and Your Research
author: Richard Hamming
summary: The article discusses Richard W. Hamming's lecture on "You and Your Research," which emphasizes the importance of setting high goals, working on important problems, having confidence, drive, and a vision of excellence. Hamming also discusses the need to look at the bigger picture and to be willing to change problem formulations to make significant contributions to a field. He emphasizes the importance of hard work, preparation, and the ability to recognize and pursue important problems.

title: The Enneagram: The Discernment Of Spirits (Introduction)
author: CherryBoyWriter

title: The friendship problem
author: Rosie Spinks
summary: The author reflects on the decline of friendships in their life and the lives of others, particularly in their 30s. They attribute this decline to various factors, such as moving away from established social networks, becoming introverted, and the changing dynamics of urban millennial friendships. The author also discusses the impact of modern technology, burnout, and the lack of low-effort, regular social interactions on the quality of friendships. They argue that the current societal emphasis on self-optimization and individualism is detrimental to the human need for social connection and support. The author concludes by suggesting that we need to reorient our lives around the idea of relying on and caring for others, rather than attempting to self-optimize and isolate ourselves.

title: Investing in the Unknown and Unknowable
author: Richard Zeckhauser
summary: Investing in the Unknown and Unknowable is an essay that explains how investors can identify good investments in situations where the level of uncertainty is well beyond that considered in traditional models of finance. The essay discusses the central principles that wise investors employ and how they have earned extraordinary returns by investing in the unknown and the unknowable. Those who lack the skills can look for "sidecar" investments that allow them to put their money alongside that of people they know to be both capable and honest. The essay also looks at behavioral economics, the tendency for humans to deviate in systematic ways from rational decision, particularly when probabilities are involved, to unearth successful investment strategies.

title: Jay Ohms - Strada: Bridging the web and native worlds - Rails World 2023
author: Ruby on Rails
summary: Jay Ohms from 37 signals introduces Strada, a framework that bridges the gap between web and native apps. Strada allows web and native apps to communicate and share state changes seamlessly. It is a component-based framework that enables developers to scale their apps effectively. With Strada, developers can create fully native controls in hybrid mobile apps driven by the web, giving them more flexibility and control over the user experience. The framework has been successfully used in their apps like Basecamp and Hey, and it offers a way to transition from old to new app versions smoothly.

title: Donal McBreen - Solid Cache: A disk backed Rails cache - Rails World 2023
author: Ruby on Rails
summary: The content discusses the implementation of a cache in a database. It compares two cache algorithms, FIFO (First In, First Out) and LRU (Least Recently Used), and explains the advantages and disadvantages of each. The author ultimately chooses to use FIFO due to its simplicity and lack of fragmentation. The process of expiring data from the cache is also explained, along with the installation process for the cache.

title: Digital Zettelkasten: Principles, Methods, & Examples
author: David Kadavy
summary: The digital Zettelkasten method, inspired by Niklas Luhmann's use of paper-based personal intranet, has gained popularity with the recent publication of S√∂nke Ahrens‚Äôs How to Take Smart Notes. The system, which involves note-taking, organizing, and linking, helps retain knowledge, organize ideas, and improve writing skills. Notes are classified into Fleeting Notes, Literature Notes, and Permanent Notes. The purpose of a Zettelkasten is not to find individual notes but to explore connections among notes and assign keywords to them. The method can be applied to digital or paper-based notes and helps users remember what they read, know what to read next, and develop ideas.

title: Gemini: A Family of Highly Capable Multimodal Models
author: Google DeepMind
summary: Gemini is a family of multimodal models developed at Google that exhibit remarkable capabilities across image, audio, video, and text understanding. The most-capable Gemini Ultra model advances the state of the art in 30 of 32 benchmarks, being the first model to achieve human-expert performance on the MMLU benchmark. Gemini models are trained to accommodate textual input interleaved with a wide variety of audio and visual inputs. The models can handle variable input resolution in order to spend more compute on tasks that require fine-grained understanding.

title: Lessons in Choreorobotics
author: Cond√© Nast
summary: Catie Cuan, an engineer and artist, discusses her work in the field of choreorobotics, which focuses on the intersection of dance and robotics. She uses her expertise in artificial intelligence to teach robots how to perform various tasks, including dancing and playing musical instruments. Cuan explains how movement is a vital aspect of a robot's perception and how choreographers can make meaning out of robot movement. She emphasizes the importance of incorporating art and culture into the development of robotics to create harmonious and dynamic interactions between humans and robots. Cuan's projects, such as Music Mode and Project Starling, have successfully demonstrated the potential for robots to evoke emotions and create novel experiences.

title: Make a map of memories
author: Herbert Lui
summary: Kai Brach, in issue 267 of Dense Discovery, shares a practice of saving kind emails from readers in a folder titled 'Confidence Boost'. These emails serve as a reminder of the importance of connection and provide a source of motivation during moments of self-doubt or creative blocks. Brach compares this practice to saving money in a bank account, as revisiting these memories pays dividends and provides energy during low moments. These memories act as a map that guides individuals when they feel lost, reminding them of their values and what truly matters to them.

title: David Foster Wallace on Responsibility and Maturity (2003)
author: Manufacturing Intellect
summary: David Foster Wallace reflects on responsibility and maturity, noting that there is a tendency for his generation to still see themselves as children. He discusses the concept of the wounded inner child and how it relates to a popular psychological movement in the United States. Wallace also explores the mixed messages young people receive in American culture about being grown-up, with a focus on gratifying personal desires while also being a responsible citizen. He expresses concern about the increasing hostility towards reading and quiet contemplation in American culture, driven by the fast-paced nature of computer and internet culture. Wallace discusses his fear of the consequences of the country's actions and its lack of awareness of the connection between its way of life and the events happening globally. He suggests that meaningful rebellion does not necessarily involve action and force, but rather quiet individualism and critical thinking.

author: fastify.dev

notes: Just testing this out, but also I do want to read it. Interesting to start to consider prioritizing what I read rather than just using a shuffle.

title: Does Bionic Reading actually work? We timed over 2,000 readers and the results might surprise you
author: Daniel Doyon
summary: tl;dr. Actually no, the results will probably not surprise you. After analyzing data from 2,074 testers, we found no evidence that Bionic Reading has any positive effect on reading speed. In fact, participants read 2.6 words per minute slower on average with Bionic Reading than without. That

title: The Next Chapter of Reader: Public Beta
author: Daniel Doyon and Tristan Homsi
summary:
Today, we're excited to announce the public beta of our own, fully-integrated reading app (known as "Reader"). Get started for free at readwise.io/read.

What is Reader? In case you missed our original manifesto, Reader is a more powerful, more flexible version of the classic read-it-later app.
